Q: A defender denies an obvious goal-scoring opportunity (DOGSO) to an opponent. Before the referee begins the disciplinary procedure, the attacking player takes a quick free kick from the correct position and creates a clear goal-scoring opportunity for a teammate. What is the decision?
openA: Allow play to continue and caution the offending player (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O1: Allow play to continue and show a Red Card to the offender at the next stoppage.
O2: Allow play to continue and caution the offending player (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O3: Allow play to continue without any disciplinary action.
O4: Stop play and show a Red Card to the offending player.

Q: A player takes a penalty kick; the goalkeeper attempts a save but does not touch the ball. The ball hits the goal post, rebounds back to the kicker, who then scores. What should the referee decide?
openA: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to the defending team.
O1: Award the goal.
O2: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to the defending team.
O3: Disallow the goal because the player is not allowed to touch the ball twice, and restart with a dropped ball.
O4: Disallow the goal.

Q: An attacking player shoots at the goal from outside the penalty area. The ball is blocked by a defender's arm, which was in a position that unnaturally enlarged the body. The goalkeeper is on the goal line. What is the correct decision?
openA: Award a penalty kick and send off the defender (Red Card).
O1: Play continues.
O2: Award a penalty kick.
O3: Award a penalty kick and send off the defender (Red Card).
O4: Award a penalty kick and caution the defender (Yellow Card).

Q: In the 63rd minute, a penalty kick is awarded. When the ball is kicked, the goalkeeper has one foot behind the goal line and the other foot in the air above the goal line. The goalkeeper saves the ball, and it leaves the field. No other offense is committed. What is the decision?
openA: Retake the penalty kick.
O1: Retake the penalty kick and caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card).
O2: Retake the penalty kick.
O3: Award a corner kick or throw-in.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball and caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card).

Q: A player accidentally touches the ball with their hand, and this accidental handball creates a goal-scoring opportunity for a teammate. What is the correct decision?
openA: Award a direct free kick.
O1: Award an indirect free kick.
O2: Award a direct free kick.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball.

Q: The referee awards a goal in the final seconds of the first half and then blows the whistle for halftime. In the locker room, an assistant referee indicates that the scorer committed an accidental handball immediately before scoring. How should the referee handle this?
openA: Award the goal because they had already left the field of play before receiving the advice.
O1: Award the goal and caution the scorer (Yellow Card).
O2: Disallow the goal.
O3: Disallow the goal and caution the scorer (Yellow Card).
O4: Award the goal because they had already left the field of play before receiving the advice.

Q: A defender throws a shinguard at the ball while an attacking player is in control of it. This action denies an obvious goal-scoring opportunity (DOGSO). The referee stops play. What is the correct disciplinary and restart decision?
openA: Red Card and award a penalty kick.
O1: Red Card and award an indirect free kick.
O2: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O3: Red Card and award a penalty kick.
O4: Yellow Card and award a penalty kick.

Q: A team official commits an offense, but the referee cannot identify the specific offender. What should be done?
openA: Sanction the highest-ranking coach in the technical area.
O1: Write an incident report.
O2: Ignore the situation.
O3: Give a public verbal warning to the technical area.
O4: Sanction the highest-ranking coach in the technical area.

Q: A goalkeeper restarts play with a free kick and touches the ball a second time before any other player has touched it, thereby stopping a promising attack (SPA). What is the correct decision?
openA: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O1: No disciplinary action, award an indirect free kick.
O2: Yellow Card and award a direct free kick.
O3: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O4: Red Card and award an indirect free kick.

Q: Team A scores a goal. Before play restarts with a kickoff, the referee is informed that there was an extra player from Team A on the field when the goal was scored. The extra player did not interfere with play. What is the decision?
openA: Disallow the goal.
O1: Award the goal.
O2: Disallow the goal.
O3: Award the goal and caution the extra player (Yellow Card).
O4: Disallow the goal and send off the extra player (Red Card).

Q: While the goalkeeper's team is attacking, the goalkeeper shouts clearly audible abusive language at a previous decision within their own penalty area. The referee stops play and cautions the goalkeeper. How is play restarted?
openA: Award an indirect free kick.
O1: Award a penalty kick.
O2: Award a direct free kick.
O3: Award an indirect free kick.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball.

Q: The referee blows the whistle to start the match, the ball is kicked backward, and at the same time, a player uses abusive language toward the referee. The referee shows a Red Card to the player. What happens next?
openA: The player sent off cannot be replaced by a named substitute.
O1: The player sent off can be replaced by a named substitute, but the number of substitutions is reduced by one.
O2: The player sent off cannot be replaced by a named substitute.
O3: The player sent off can be replaced by a named substitute.
O4: The player sent off can continue the match.

Q: A free kick is taken by the defending team in their own penalty area. An attacking player who did not have time to leave the area intercepts the ball and shoots. The ball is saved by the goalkeeper and goes directly over the goal line. How should play be restarted?
openA: Retake the free kick; the attacker must be outside the area before play restarts.
O1: Retake the free kick; the attacker must be outside the area before play restarts.
O2: Award a goal kick.
O3: Award a corner kick.
O4: Award a throw-in.

Q: At the moment a teammate passes the ball, an attacker in an offside position inside the penalty area is pulled by a defender, which denies an obvious goal-scoring opportunity. What is the decision?
openA: Penalize the offside offense and restart with an indirect free kick.
O1: Penalize the more serious foul (Penalty Kick) and send off the defender.
O2: Penalize the more serious foul (Penalty Kick) and caution the defender.
O3: Penalize the offside offense and restart with an indirect free kick.
O4: Penalize the offside offense (interfering with an opponent) and restart with an indirect free kick.

Q: Two players from the same team collide heads and are injured. What action should the referee take?
openA: All of the above may be appropriate.
O1: Serious injury: stop play immediately and allow medical staff to enter.
O2: Once treated, the referee allows both players to remain on the field.
O3: Restart play with a dropped ball.
O4: All of the above may be appropriate.

Q: A defending player receiving treatment off the field enters the field without permission and stops the ball with their foot to prevent it from entering their own goal. What is the decision?
openA: Award a penalty kick, show a Yellow Card, then a Red Card.
O1: Award a penalty kick and caution the player (Yellow Card).
O2: Award a penalty kick, show a Yellow Card for entering without permission, and a Red Card for DOGSO.
O3: Award a penalty kick, show two Yellow Cards followed by a Red Card.
O4: Allow play to continue and caution the player when the ball is next out of play.

Q: A goalkeeper takes a goal kick. After play is restarted, but still inside their own penalty area, the goalkeeper touches the ball a second time before any other player. This second touch denies an obvious goal-scoring opportunity. What is the decision?
openA: Send off the goalkeeper and award an indirect free kick.
O1: Send off the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.
O2: Award an indirect free kick with no disciplinary action.
O3: Send off the goalkeeper and award an indirect free kick.
O4: Caution the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.

Q: A goalkeeper has already been warned/cautioned during the match. During a penalty shootout, the goalkeeper commits an offense that clearly impacts the kicker, who then misses. What is the decision?
openA: Caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card) and retake the penalty kick.
O1: Caution the goalkeeper (Red Card), send them off, and retake the penalty kick.
O2: Caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card) and retake the penalty kick.
O3: Warn the goalkeeper and retake the penalty kick.
O4: No disciplinary action, recorded as a miss.

Q: During a free kick within the penalty area, the goalkeeper uses a 'trick' to handle a ball deliberately kicked back by a teammate. What is the decision?
openA: Award an indirect free kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O1: Award a penalty kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O2: Order a retake of the free kick.
O3: Award an indirect free kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O4: Award an indirect free kick and caution the teammate who initiated the backpass.

Q: A defender carelessly trips an opponent outside the penalty area, denying a DOGSO. The referee awards a free kick and allows a quick restart. The attacker passes to a teammate in an offside position. The AR signals for offside. What is the decision?
openA: Offside offense, award an indirect free kick, and caution the defender.
O1: Offside offense, award an indirect free kick, and caution the defender (Yellow Card).
O2: Tripping foul, award a direct free kick, and caution the defender.
O3: Tripping foul, award a direct free kick, and send off the defender (Red Card).
O4: Award a direct free kick without any disciplinary action.

Q: An attacking player accidentally handles the ball and then passes it to a teammate who immediately has an obvious goal-scoring opportunity. The referee should penalize the player for a handball offense.
openA: False.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If a player commits a cautionable offense (Yellow Card) and the referee plays advantage, and then the same player commits another cautionable offense, the player must be sent off for receiving two cautions when the referee stops play.
openA: False.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A goalkeeper taking a goal kick flicks the ball up to a teammate, who heads it back to the goalkeeper. The goalkeeper then handles the ball inside their own penalty area. The referee should award an indirect free kick and caution the goalkeeper.
openA: False.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: The color of undershorts/tights must be the same as the main color of the shorts or the lowest part (hem) of the shorts, and the whole team must wear the same color. This same rule applies to undershirts and the jersey sleeves.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: The referee may send off a player with a Red Card or caution them with a Yellow Card before the match starts. This caution is carried into the match, and if the player is cautioned again during the game, they will be sent off.
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If it is impossible to accurately identify which team official committed an offense, the disciplinary sanction shall be given to the team leader (manager) with the highest rank in the technical area.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If a player on the field commits an offense against an outside agent inside the field of play and the referee stops the match, the restart is a dropped ball.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If a player leaves the field due to an equipment issue (boots, jersey, etc.) and has been checked by a match official, they must wait until the next stoppage in play to re-enter with the referee's permission.
openA: False.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Once the referee decides to caution or send off a player, play must not be restarted until the disciplinary procedure is completed, unless the non-offending team takes a quick free kick and has a clear goal-scoring opportunity before the procedure begins.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If a player enters the field of play without the referee's permission and then stops a promising attack (SPA) with a foul, they should receive two separate cautions (Yellow Cards).
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: During a penalty shootout, if a retake is ordered due to a goalkeeper's offense, the referee should:
openA: Warn the goalkeeper for the first offense; any subsequent offenses result in a caution.
O1: Warn the goalkeeper for the first offense; any subsequent offenses result in a caution.
O2: Only warn the goalkeeper without issuing a Yellow Card.
O3: Must caution the goalkeeper with a Yellow Card immediately.
O4: If already cautioned earlier in the shootout, only a warning is needed.

Q: If the ball touches a match official and remains on the field, play is restarted with a dropped ball for the team that last touched it (except when inside the penalty area) if:
openA: All other options are correct.
O1: All other options are correct.
O2: Possession of the ball changes.
O3: The ball goes directly into the goal.
O4: A team starts a promising attack.

Q: How should the referee handle a situation where two players commit offenses at the same time during play?
openA: Penalize the more serious offense and restart accordingly.
O1: Penalize the more serious offense and restart accordingly.
O2: Stop play and caution both players.
O3: Stop play and restart with an indirect free kick.
O4: Stop play and restart with a dropped ball.

Q: A goalkeeper taking a free kick in their own penalty area slips; the ball moves clearly and they then pick it up with their hands to prevent an opponent from challenging for it. What is the decision?
openA: Award an indirect free kick.
O1: Award an indirect free kick and send off the goalkeeper (Red Card) if it denied a DOGSO.
O2: Award a penalty kick and send off the goalkeeper.
O3: Award a penalty kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O4: Award an indirect free kick with no disciplinary action.

Q: Advantage is played after a foul, but the ball is passed to a teammate in an offside position. The AR signals for offside. How should the referee rule?
openA: Penalize whichever offense occurred first or is deemed more appropriate by the referee.
O1: Penalize the defender's foul.
O2: Penalize the attacker's offside.
O3: Penalize the defender's foul if it occurred first, otherwise penalize offside.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball.

Q: If Additional Assistant Referees (AARs) are appointed and Goal Line Technology is not used, where should the Assistant Referee (AR) be during a penalty shootout?
openA: One AR at the center circle, the other behind the goalkeeper in the waiting area.
O1: Both Assistant Referees at the center circle.
O2: One at the center circle, one in the technical area.
O3: One at the center circle, one at the corner flag.
O4: One at the center circle, the other behind the goalkeeper in the waiting area.

Q: A player is cautioned (Yellow Card) for removing their shirt to celebrate a goal. The referee subsequently disallows the goal. What happens to the Yellow Card?
openA: The Yellow Card for the celebration offense remains valid even if the goal is disallowed.
O1: The caution is canceled because the goal was disallowed.
O2: All other options are incorrect.
O3: The card only stands if it was shown before the goal was disallowed.
O4: The Yellow Card for the celebration offense remains valid even if the goal is disallowed.

Q: A named substitute starts the match instead of a named starting player without the referee being informed. How should the referee handle this?
openA: Allow play to continue and report the matter; no reduction in substitution opportunities.
O1: Allow play to continue and caution the player at the next stoppage.
O2: Allow play to continue and report the matter; no reduction in substitution opportunities.
O3: Stop play, caution the substitute, and restart with an indirect free kick.
O4: Allow play to continue, but reduce the team's substitution limit.

Q: A substitute enters their own penalty area and stops a ball going into the goal with their foot. What is the decision?
openA: Stop play, send off the substitute for DOGSO, and restart with a penalty kick.
O1: Stop play, send off the substitute for DOGSO, and restart with a penalty kick.
O2: Stop play, caution for entering without permission, restart with a penalty kick.
O3: Stop play, caution for entering without permission, restart with an indirect free kick.
O4: Stop play, send off for DOGSO, restart with an indirect free kick.

Q: In which of the following cases is a player NOT required to leave the field for medical treatment?
openA: All other options are correct.
O1: A penalty kicker receiving quick treatment before taking the kick.
O2: All other options are correct.
O3: A goalkeeper and an outfield player colliding and requiring treatment.
O4: A player injured by a foul for which the opponent was cautioned or sent off.

Q: A player receives a Yellow Card during extra time. During the subsequent penalty shootout, the same player receives another Yellow Card. How should the referee proceed?
openA: Yellow Cards from the match are not carried into the shootout; the player is not sent off.
O1: Yellow Cards from the match are not carried into the shootout; the player is not sent off.
O2: Follow competition rules as the Laws are silent.
O3: If the player is a goalkeeper, they are not sent off.
O4: The player is sent off for receiving a second caution.

Q: A player carelessly trips an opponent outside the penalty area, denying a DOGSO. The attacking team takes a quick free kick and creates a goal-scoring opportunity but fails to score. What is the disciplinary decision?
openA: Allow the quick free kick and caution the defender (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O1: Allow the quick free kick and caution the defender (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O2: Allow the quick free kick and take no further disciplinary action.
O3: Allow the quick free kick and send off the defender (Red Card).
O4: Do not allow the quick free kick; stop play and send off the defender immediately.

Q: If the referee realizes after a goal is scored but before the restart that an extra substitute from the scoring team was on the field, what is the decision?
openA: Goal disallowed; restart with a direct free kick or penalty where the extra player was.
O1: Goal disallowed; restart with a direct free kick or penalty where the extra player was.
O2: Goal disallowed; restart with an indirect free kick where play was stopped.
O3: Goal is valid if the extra player did not interfere with play; restart with a kickoff.
O4: Goal disallowed; restart with a direct free kick where the ball was.

Q: If a player on the field throws an object at an opposing substitute standing off the field, how is play restarted?
openA: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O1: Direct free kick at the ball's position when play was stopped.
O2: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O3: Indirect free kick where the ball was.
O4: Dropped ball where the ball was.

Q: During a dropped ball, a player kicks the ball directly into their own goal before it touches any other player. How is play restarted?
openA: Corner kick to the opponent.
O1: Retake the dropped ball.
O2: Goal kick.
O3: Goal is awarded.
O4: Corner kick to the opponent.

Q: A player who was excluded from the penalty shootout to equalize team numbers. Can they still participate?
openA: Yes, they can replace a goalkeeper who is unable to continue.
O1: No, excluded players cannot participate.
O2: Yes, but only if the team has not used all substitutions.
O3: Yes, they can replace a goalkeeper who is unable to continue.
O4: Yes, they can replace any player unable to continue if subs remain.

Q: A substitute throws an object onto the field, interfering with play, an opponent, or a match official. How is play restarted?
openA: Direct free kick (or penalty) at the position of interference.
O1: Indirect free kick where the object interfered with play.
O2: Direct free kick on the boundary line nearest the substitute.
O3: Direct free kick (or penalty) at the position of interference.
O4: Indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest the substitute.

Q: In which restart situations can a player be cautioned for failing to respect the required distance?
openA: Corner kick, Dropped ball, Free kick, Throw-in.
O1: Corner kick, Free kick, Throw-in.
O2: Corner kick, Goal kick, Free kick, Throw-in.
O3: Corner kick, Dropped ball, Free kick, Throw-in.
O4: Corner kick, Goal kick, Free kick.

Q: During a penalty kick, a teammate of the designated kicker takes the kick and scores. What is the decision?
openA: Goal disallowed, caution the kicker, restart with an indirect free kick for the defense.
O1: Goal disallowed, caution the kicker, and retake the penalty.
O2: Goal disallowed, restart with an indirect free kick for the defense.
O3: Goal is valid.
O4: Goal disallowed, caution the kicker, restart with an indirect free kick for the defense.

Q: A player on the field commits an offense against a team official of their own team off the field. How is play restarted?
openA: Indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O1: Dropped ball where the ball was.
O2: All answers could be correct depending on severity.
O3: Indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O4: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.

Q: The referee awards a goal in the final seconds of the first half and then blows the whistle for halftime. In the locker room, an assistant referee indicates that the scorer committed an accidental handball immediately before scoring. How should the referee handle this?
openA: Award the goal because they had already left the field of play before receiving the advice.
O1: Award the goal, but caution the scorer with a Yellow Card.
O2: Disallow the goal and caution the scorer with a Yellow Card.
O3: Award the goal because they had already left the field of play before receiving the advice.
O4: Disallow the goal.

Q: When three or more defending players form a 'wall,' an attacking player stands within 1 meter of the wall before the free kick is taken. What is the referee's decision?
openA: Stop play and award an indirect free kick to the opposing team.
O1: Stop play and award a direct free kick to the opposing team.
O2: Stop play, caution the player, and order a retake of the free kick.
O3: Stop play and award an indirect free kick to the opposing team.
O4: Stop play, caution the player, and award an indirect free kick to the opposing team.

Q: Which of the following situations is IRRELEVANT to the procedure of dropping the ball to the goalkeeper in their own penalty area?
openA: An injured player is inside the penalty area.
O1: The attacking team was in possession inside the penalty area.
O2: The ball was inside the penalty area.
O3: An injured player is inside the penalty area.
O4: The last touch of the ball was inside the penalty area.

Q: A named substitute starts the match instead of a named starting player without the referee being informed. How should the referee handle this?
openA: Allow play to continue and report the matter; no reduction in substitution opportunities.
O1: Allow play to continue and caution the player at the next stoppage.
O2: Stop play, caution the substitute, and restart with an indirect free kick.
O3: Allow play to continue, but reduce the team's substitution limit.
O4: Allow play to continue and report the matter; no reduction in substitution opportunities.

Q: During play, a player on the field strikes a teammate while outside the field of play. How is play restarted?
openA: Indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O1: Indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O2: Indirect free kick where the ball was when play was stopped.
O3: Direct free kick on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O4: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.

Q: A goalkeeper takes a goal kick. The ball touches the referee outside the penalty area, remains on the field, and rebounds back toward the goal. The goalkeeper handles the ball to prevent it from entering the goal. What is the decision?
openA: Restart with a dropped ball at the location where the ball touched the referee.
O1: Retake the goal kick.
O2: Allow play to continue.
O3: Award an indirect free kick to the opposing team.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball at the location where the ball touched the referee.

Q: A defender flicks the ball up with their foot and headers it back to their goalkeeper, who then handles it inside their own penalty area. The referee awards an indirect free kick and cautions the defender.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A player is cautioned (Yellow Card) for removing their shirt to celebrate a goal. The referee subsequently disallows the goal. What happens to the Yellow Card?
openA: The caution remains valid even if the goal is disallowed.
O1: The caution is canceled if it was shown before the goal was disallowed.
O2: The caution remains valid even if the goal is disallowed.
O3: All other options are incorrect.
O4: The caution is canceled because the goal was disallowed.

Q: If the ball is about to enter the goal but is touched by an outside agent (not a player) and then enters the goal, the referee can award the goal if the touch did not impact the defending team (unless the interference was from the attacking team).
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: While the goalkeeper's team is attacking, the goalkeeper shouts abusive language within their own penalty area. The referee stops play and cautions the goalkeeper. How is play restarted?
openA: Award an indirect free kick.
O1: Award a direct free kick.
O2: Award an indirect free kick.
O3: Restart with a dropped ball.
O4: Award a penalty kick.

Q: Which of the following actions by a team official will result in a Red Card (Sending-off)?
openA: Deliberately throwing or kicking an object onto the field.
O1: Excessively signaling for a Red or Yellow Card.
O2: Deliberately throwing or kicking an object onto the field.
O3: Delaying the restart of play by their own team.
O4: Using provocative or inflammatory gestures/behavior.

Q: The distance of the penalty mark from the goal is measured from the center of the mark to the inner edge of the goal line.
openA: False.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: If it is impossible to accurately identify which team official committed an offense, the highest-ranking official in the technical area will receive the disciplinary sanction.
openA: True.
O1: False
O2: True

Q: A player accidentally handles the ball, and this accidental handball immediately creates a goal-scoring opportunity for a teammate. What is the correct decision?
openA: Award a direct free kick
O1: Allow play to continue
O2: Award a direct free kick
O3: Restart with a dropped ball
O4: Award an indirect free kick

Q: Under what circumstance is a player in an offside position considered to have 'gained an advantage'?
openA: Playing a ball that rebounds or is deflected off a deliberate save by an opponent.
O1: An opponent deliberately plays the ball.
O2: An opponent makes a deliberate save.
O3: All other options are incorrect.
O4: An opponent deliberately handles the ball.

Q: If a player on the field throws an object at an opposing substitute standing off the field, how is play restarted?
openA: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O1: Indirect free kick where the ball was.
O2: Direct free kick at the ball's position when play was stopped.
O3: Direct free kick (or penalty) on the boundary line nearest to the offense.
O4: Dropped ball where the ball was.

Q: A player who was excluded from the penalty shootout to equalize team numbers. Can they still participate?
openA: Yes, they can replace a goalkeeper who is unable to continue.
O1: Yes, they can replace a goalkeeper who is unable to continue.
O2: No, excluded players cannot participate.
O3: Yes, but only if the team has not used all substitutions.
O4: Yes, they can replace any player if substitutions remain.

Q: If the referee realizes after a goal but before the restart that an extra substitute from the scoring team was on the field, what is the decision?
openA: Goal disallowed; restart with a direct free kick or penalty where the extra player was located.
O1: Goal disallowed; indirect free kick where play was stopped.
O2: Goal valid if the extra player did not interfere.
O3: Goal disallowed; restart with a direct free kick or penalty where the extra player was located.
O4: Goal disallowed; direct free kick where the ball was.

Q: The referee may send off a player before the match starts. A caution (Yellow Card) given before the match is carried into the game; if the player is cautioned again during the match, they will be sent off.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A dropped ball is only awarded if the ball touches a match official and remains in play. If it touches an official and leaves the field, the restart is the same as if it had not touched the official.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Which of the following is correct regarding the dropped ball procedure?
openA: All other players (from both teams) must remain at least 4 meters away.
O1: All other players must remain at least 4 meters away.
O2: Opposing players (excluding teammates) must remain at least 4 meters away.
O3: All other players must remain at least 5 meters away.
O4: Opposing players must remain at least 9.15 meters away.

Q: A player is cautioned (Yellow Card) during extra time. During the subsequent penalty shootout, the same player receives another Yellow Card. How should the referee proceed?
openA: Yellow Cards from the match are not carried into the shootout; the player is not sent off.
O1: The player is sent off for receiving a second caution.
O2: If the player is a goalkeeper, they are not sent off.
O3: Follow competition rules as the Laws are silent.
O4: Yellow Cards from the match are not carried into the shootout; the player is not sent off.

Q: A goalkeeper takes a goal kick. After the ball is in play, the goalkeeper touches the ball a second time with their hand before another player has touched it, denying a DOGSO. The referee should:
openA: Award an indirect free kick; no disciplinary action is taken against the goalkeeper.
O1: Award an indirect free kick; no disciplinary action.
O2: Award an indirect free kick and disallow no disciplinary action.
O3: Send off the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.
O4: Caution the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.

Q: Cautions and warnings issued during the match are not carried forward into the penalty shootout.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: During a penalty kick, the goalkeeper and the kicker commit an offense at the same time. How should the referee handle this?
openA: Regardless of whether the goal is scored, only the kicker is cautioned, and play restarts with an indirect free kick.
O1: If no goal, caution the goalkeeper and retake.
O2: Caution both and retake.
O3: Regardless of whether the goal is scored, only the kicker is cautioned, and play restarts with an indirect free kick.
O4: If goal is scored, caution the kicker and retake.

Q: In which of the following cases is a player NOT required to leave the field for medical treatment?
openA: All other options are correct.
O1: Goalkeeper and outfield player collision.
O2: All other options are correct.
O3: Injury caused by a foul where the opponent was cautioned or sent off.
O4: Penalty kicker receiving quick treatment before the kick.

Q: If competition rules allow an additional substitute during extra time, both teams are granted one additional substitution opportunity.
openA: True.
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A substitute enters their own penalty area and blocks a ball going into the goal with their foot. What is the decision?
openA: Stop play, send off the substitute for DOGSO, and award a penalty kick.
O1: Stop play, caution for entering without permission, restart with IFK.
O2: Stop play, send off the substitute for DOGSO, and award a penalty kick.
O3: Stop play, send off for DOGSO, restart with IFK.
O4: Stop play, caution for entering without permission, restart with penalty.

Q: A spectator blows a whistle. A defender inside their own penalty area, thinking the referee has stopped play, picks up the ball with their hands. What is the referee's decision?
openA: Stop play and restart with a dropped ball.
O1: Stop play and restart with a dropped ball.
O2: Stop play and award a penalty kick or a direct free kick.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: All of the above are incorrect.

Q: If a player kicks the ball directly into the opponent's goal from a dropped ball, what is the referee's decision?
openA: Restart with a goal kick.
O1: Restart with a goal kick.
O2: Restart with a corner kick.
O3: Award the goal.
O4: Retake the dropped ball.

Q: Can a goalkeeper be penalized with a free kick for a handball offense within their own penalty area?
openA: Yes, but only with an indirect free kick.
O1: Never.
O2: Yes, but only with an indirect free kick.
O3: Yes, they could be penalized with a direct free kick or penalty kick.
O4: All of the above are incorrect.

Q: Can the referee show a Yellow or Red Card to a player during the halftime interval?
openA: Yes, the referee has the authority to show cards during the halftime interval.
O1: Yes, but only on the field of play or on the way to the dressing room.
O2: Yes, the referee has the authority to show cards during the halftime interval.
O3: Yes, but only if they are on the field of play.
O4: Yes, but only within the field of play and its immediate surrounding area.

Q: During a university match, an attacker falls after a challenge in the penalty area and the ball goes out of play. The referee initially awards a penalty. An Assistant Referee with a better view informs the referee via headset that the defender played the ball cleanly. The referee cancels the penalty. How should play be restarted?
openA: Dropped ball to the defending goalkeeper.
O1: Dropped ball to the defender at the spot of the challenge.
O2: Indirect free kick for the defending team.
O3: Corner kick.
O4: Dropped ball to the defending goalkeeper.

Q: Which of the following statements regarding 'tackling/challenging an opponent' is correct?
openA: All of the above are correct.
O1: Touching the ball first does not necessarily mean no foul has been committed.
O2: If a player touches the ball and then the opponent due to natural momentum within reasonable intensity, it is not a foul.
O3: A player may tackle/challenge an opponent from the front, side, or behind.
O4: All of the above are correct.

Q: After scoring a goal, a player takes off their gloves and waves them to celebrate. What is the referee's decision?
openA: Goal is valid; no disciplinary action.
O1: Goal is valid; caution the player (Yellow Card) for removing equipment.
O2: Goal is valid; no disciplinary action.
O3: Goal is disallowed; caution the player (Yellow Card).
O4: Goal is disallowed.

Q: A player who left the field to adjust equipment re-enters without permission and stops a promising attack (SPA) by handling the ball. What is the referee's decision?
openA: Show two separate Yellow Cards (one for entry, one for SPA).
O1: Show one Yellow Card.
O2: Show one Red Card.
O3: Show two separate Yellow Cards (one for entry, one for SPA).
O4: Allow play to continue.

Q: During play, a player leaves the field and strikes a substitute from their own team on the bench. How is play restarted?
openA: Red Card (Sending-off) and an indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest the offense.
O1: Red Card and restart with a dropped ball.
O2: Red Card and an indirect free kick on the boundary line nearest the offense.
O3: Red Card and a direct free kick on the boundary line nearest the offense.
O4: Red Card and an indirect free kick where the ball was when play stopped.

Q: An attacking player accidentally handles the ball, then passes it to a teammate who scores. What is the referee's decision?
openA: Disallow goal; award a direct free kick for handball.
O1: Goal is valid.
O2: Disallow goal; award a direct free kick for handball.
O3: Disallow goal; award a direct free kick inside the penalty area.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball for the defending goalkeeper.

Q: During a penalty kick, the ball hits the junction of the crossbar and post and returns to the field. The referee then notices the ball has burst. What is the decision?
openA: Stop play, replace the ball, and restart with a dropped ball.
O1: Stop play, replace the ball, and restart with a dropped ball.
O2: Stop play, replace the ball, and award an indirect free kick to the defense.
O3: Stop play, replace the ball, and award a direct free kick to the defense.
O4: Stop play, replace the ball, and retake the penalty kick.

Q: Which of the following actions by a team official results in a Red Card (Sending-off)?
openA: Deliberately throwing or kicking an object onto the field.
O1: Clearly/persistently failing to respect technical area boundaries.
O2: Entering the Referee Review Area (RRA).
O3: Deliberately throwing or kicking an object onto the field.
O4: Using provocative or inflammatory gestures or behavior.

Q: When determining the nature of 'striking or attempting to strike' an opponent, which factors should be considered?
openA: All of the above are correct.
O1: The intent of the strike.
O2: The part of the body used and the part of the opponent struck.
O3: The force and speed of the strike.
O4: All of the above are correct.

Q: A goalkeeper handles a ball in their own goal area that was deliberately kicked to them by a teammate. How is play restarted?
openA: Indirect free kick on the goal area line parallel to the goal line nearest the offense.
O1: Penalty kick.
O2: Indirect free kick at the spot where the goalkeeper touched the ball.
O3: Indirect free kick on the goal area line parallel to the goal line nearest the offense.
O4: Indirect free kick on the goal area line parallel to the touchline.

Q: During an indirect free kick, the kicker shoots directly at the goal. The goalkeeper touches the ball, and it enters the goal. What is the decision?
openA: Goal is valid; restart with a kickoff.
O1: Restart with a goal kick.
O2: Retake the indirect free kick.
O3: Award an indirect free kick to the defense.
O4: Goal is valid; restart with a kickoff.

Q: During a match, a player enters the Referee Review Area (RRA) while the referee is conducting an on-field review. What is the decision?
openA: Caution the player (Yellow Card).
O1: No card, verbal warning only.
O2: No action required.
O3: Caution the player (Yellow Card).
O4: Send off the player (Red Card).

Q: In a professional match, both goalkeepers have jerseys of the same color and no alternative kit is available. What should the referee do?
openA: Instruct the visiting (away) team goalkeeper to change.
O1: Instruct the home team goalkeeper to change.
O2: Instruct the visiting (away) team goalkeeper to change.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Allow play to continue and report the incident to the authorities.

Q: During a penalty shootout (KFPM), the kicker shoots and the ball goes over the bar. The goalkeeper encroached but did not react. The goalkeeper had already been cautioned during regular time. What is the decision?
openA: Goal disallowed (miss), warn the goalkeeper; warning does not lead to a Red Card.
O1: Retake if the offense impacted the kicker; otherwise, it is a miss. Warn the goalkeeper (Reset for KFPM).
O2: Retake the penalty and caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card).
O3: Retake the penalty, caution the goalkeeper (Red Card due to second Yellow).
O4: Recorded as a miss; no further action.

Q: During a penalty kick, a player is injured and treated on the field. The injured player wishes to take the penalty kick. What is the decision?
openA: The player may stay on the field and take the penalty kick.
O1: The player may stay on the field and take the penalty kick.
O2: The player must leave the field because the offender was not cautioned.
O3: The player must leave the field because the offender was not sent off.
O4: The player may stay on the field regardless of who takes the kick.

Q: A defender begins pulling an attacker outside the penalty area but continues the pulling until they are inside the penalty area. What is the decision?
openA: Award a penalty kick.
O1: Award a penalty kick.
O2: Award a direct free kick at the spot where the pulling started.
O3: Award an indirect free kick inside the penalty area.
O4: Allow play to continue.

Q: A defender denies an obvious goal-scoring opportunity (DOGSO). Before the referee starts the disciplinary procedure, the attacking team takes a quick free kick and creates a clear goal-scoring opportunity for a teammate. What is the decision?
openA: Allow play to continue and caution the offender (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O1: Allow play to continue and show a Red Card to the offender at the next stoppage.
O2: Allow play to continue and caution the offender (Yellow Card) at the next stoppage.
O3: Allow play to continue without any disciplinary action.
O4: Stop play and show a Red Card to the offending player.

Q: A player takes a penalty kick; the goalkeeper attempts a save but does not touch the ball. The ball hits the goal post and rebounds to the kicker, who then scores. What is the decision?
openA: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to the defending team.
O1: Award the goal.
O2: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to the defending team.
O3: Disallow the goal because a double touch is not allowed, and restart with a dropped ball.
O4: Disallow the goal.

Q: An attacker shoots from outside the penalty area. The ball is blocked by a defender's arm inside the area, which was in a position that unnaturally enlarged the body. The goalkeeper is on the goal line. What is the decision?
openA: Award a penalty kick and caution the defender (Yellow Card).
O1: Allow play to continue.
O2: Award a penalty kick.
O3: Award a penalty kick and send off the defender (Red Card).
O4: Award a penalty kick and caution the defender (Yellow Card).

Q: During a penalty kick, the goalkeeper has one foot on the goal line and the other foot in the air above the goal line when the ball is kicked. The goalkeeper saves the ball, and it leaves the field. No other offense is committed. What is the decision?
openA: Award a corner kick or throw-in (No offense).
O1: Retake the penalty kick and caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card).
O2: Retake the penalty kick.
O3: Award a corner kick or throw-in.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball and caution the goalkeeper (Yellow Card).

Q: A player accidentally handles the ball, and this accidental handball creates a goal-scoring opportunity for a teammate. What is the correct decision?
openA: Award a direct free kick.
O1: Award an indirect free kick.
O2: Award a direct free kick.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball.

Q: The referee awards a goal in the final seconds of the first half and then blows for halftime. In the locker room, an AR indicates the scorer accidentally handled the ball immediately before scoring. How should the referee proceed?
openA: Award the goal because they had already left the field before the advice.
O1: Award the goal and caution the scorer (Yellow Card).
O2: Disallow the goal.
O3: Disallow the goal and caution the scorer (Yellow Card).
O4: Award the goal because they had already left the field before the advice.

Q: A defender throws a shinguard at the ball inside the box while an attacker is in control of it, denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity (DOGSO). The referee stops play. What is the decision?
openA: Red Card and award a penalty kick.
O1: Red Card and award an indirect free kick.
O2: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O3: Red Card and award a penalty kick.
O4: Yellow Card and award a penalty kick.

Q: A team official commits an offense, but the referee cannot identify the specific offender. What should be done?
openA: Sanction the highest-ranking coach in the technical area.
O1: Write an incident report.
O2: Ignore the situation.
O3: Give a public verbal warning to the technical area.
O4: Sanction the highest-ranking coach in the technical area.

Q: A goalkeeper restarts with a free kick and touches the ball a second time before another player, stopping a promising attack (SPA). What is the decision?
openA: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O1: No disciplinary action, award an indirect free kick.
O2: Yellow Card and award a direct free kick.
O3: Yellow Card and award an indirect free kick.
O4: Red Card and award an indirect free kick.

Q: Team A scores. Before the kickoff, the referee is informed an extra player from Team A was on the field when the goal was scored but did not interfere. What is the decision?
openA: Award the goal.
O1: Award the goal.
O2: Disallow the goal.
O3: Award the goal and caution the extra player.
O4: Disallow the goal and send off the extra player.

Q: While the goalkeeper's team is attacking, the goalkeeper shouts abusive language within their own penalty area. The referee stops play and cautions the goalkeeper. How is play restarted?
openA: Award an indirect free kick.
O1: Award a penalty kick.
O2: Award a direct free kick.
O3: Award an indirect free kick.
O4: Restart with a dropped ball.

Q: After the whistle to start the match and the ball is kicked, a player uses abusive language toward the referee and is sent off. What happens next?
openA: The player sent off cannot be replaced by a substitute.
O1: The player can be replaced, but the team loses one substitution opportunity.
O2: The player sent off cannot be replaced by a substitute.
O3: The player can be replaced by a named substitute.
O4: The player can continue play.

Q: A free kick is taken by the defense in their own penalty area. An attacker who didn't have time to leave intercepts the ball and shoots. The ball goes over the goal line. How is play restarted?
openA: Award a corner kick.
O1: Retake the free kick.
O2: Award a goal kick.
O3: Award a corner kick.
O4: Award a throw-in.

Q: An attacker in an offside position is pulled by a defender in the penalty area, denying a DOGSO. What is the decision?
openA: Penalize the offside offense and award an indirect free kick.
O1: Penalize the foul (Penalty) and send off the defender.
O2: Penalize the foul (Penalty) and caution the defender.
O3: Penalize the offside offense and award an indirect free kick.
O4: Penalize offside for interfering with an opponent.

Q: Two teammates collide heads and are injured. What action should be taken?
openA: All of the above.
O1: Stop play and allow medical staff to enter.
O2: Once treated, the referee allows both players to remain on the field.
O3: Restart with a dropped ball.
O4: All of the above.

Q: A defender receiving treatment re-enters without permission and stops the ball with their foot to prevent a goal. What is the decision?
openA: Award a penalty kick and show both a Yellow Card and a Red Card.
O1: Award a penalty kick and caution the player.
O2: Award a penalty kick and show both a Yellow Card and a Red Card.
O3: Award a penalty kick and show two Yellow Cards followed by a Red Card.
O4: Allow play to continue and caution the player later.

Q: A goalkeeper takes a goal kick. After play restarts but before another player touches it, the goalkeeper touches the ball again inside the area to deny a DOGSO. What is the decision?
openA: Send off the goalkeeper and award an indirect free kick.
O1: Send off the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.
O2: Award an indirect free kick; no disciplinary action.
O3: Send off the goalkeeper and award an indirect free kick.
O4: Caution the goalkeeper and award a penalty kick.

Q: During a penalty shootout, a previously cautioned goalkeeper commits an offense that impacts the kicker, who then misses. What is the decision?
openA: Warn the goalkeeper and retake the penalty kick.
O1: Show a second Yellow Card, send off the goalkeeper, and retake.
O2: No action
O3: Warn the goalkeeper and retake the penalty kick.
O4: No action, recorded as a miss.

Q: During a free kick in the penalty area, the goalkeeper uses a trick to handle a ball deliberately kicked back by a teammate. What is the decision?
openA: Award an indirect free kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O1: Award a penalty kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O2: Retake the free kick.
O3: Award an indirect free kick and caution the goalkeeper.
O4: Award an indirect free kick and caution the teammate.

Q: A defender carelessly trips an opponent outside the area, denying a DOGSO. The referee allows a quick free kick, but the attacker passes to an offside teammate. The AR signals offside. What is the decision?
openA: Offside offense, award an indirect free kick and caution the original defender.
O1: Offside offense, award an indirect free kick and caution the original defender.
O2: Tripping foul, award a direct free kick and caution the defender.
O3: Tripping foul, award a direct free kick and send off the defender.
O4: Direct free kick, no disciplinary action.

Q: The ball goes directly into the opponent's goal from a corner kick. The referee should:
O1: Disallow the goal.
O2: None of the presented answers are correct.
O3: Allow the goal.
O4: Allow the goal only if the ball was played twice before entering the goal.
openA: Allow the goal.

Q: If opposing teams choose to be on opposite sides of the field, they:
O1: must be directly opposite each other.
O2: are not allowed to be on opposite sides.
O3: may be diagonally across from each other.
O4: must make prior arrangements and notify the referee before the game.
openA: may be diagonally across from each other.

Q: What goal differential will terminate the game when attained at the end of the first half or secured at any point during the second half?
Player A2 is in an offside position when player A3 takes a shot on goal which the goalkeeper attempts to save and rebounds from the goalkeeper to A2. A2 shoots and scores. Ruling:
O1: Disallow the goal and award a penalty kick to Team A.
O2: Disallow the goal and award a goal kick to Team B.
O3: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O4: Allow the goal.
openA: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to Team B.

Q: A player shall be disqualified, without caution, by the official when he or she has completed the following action:
O1: Flagrantly fouling the goalkeeper in possession of the ball.
O2: Faking an injury.
O3: Hand ball.
O4: Kicking the ball out of bounds.
openA: Flagrantly fouling the goalkeeper in possession of the ball.

Q: For any delayed, excessive or prolonged act(s) by which a player(s) attempts to focus attention upon himself/herself and/or prohibits a timely restart of the game:
O1: The player shall be cautioned.
O2: The referee need not take any action.
O3: The player shall be warned (yellow card).
O4: The player shall be disqualified (red card).
openA: The player shall be cautioned.

Q: Any delayed, excessive or prolonged act(s) by which a player(s) attempts to focus attention upon himself/herself and/or prohibits a timely restart of the game, shall be issued what 7 card?
O1: Blue Card Only
O2: Yellow Card Only
O3: Red Card Only
O4: Yellow/Red Combination
openA: Yellow/Red Combination

Q: The defending team kicks the ball across the goal line near the corner flag. The corner area on that side of the field is very muddy.
O1: The game is abandoned due to unplayable surface.
O2: The kick must be taken from the correct corner regardless of the muddy conditions.
O3: The kick can be taken from outside the corner arc.
O4: The referee should permit the attacking team to take the corner kick from the other side of the field.
openA: The kick must be taken from the correct corner regardless of the muddy conditions.

Q: The goalkeeper, before taking a goal kick, moves the spotted ball from the right side of the goal area to the left side of the goal area.
O1: The referee shall stop the clock and restart once the ball is put into play.
O2: If this is deemed a time-wasting ploy, the referee shall caution the goalkeeper.
O3: This is allowed.
O4: If this is considered time-wasting, the referee shall award an indirect kick.
openA: If this is deemed a time-wasting ploy, the referee shall caution the goalkeeper.

Q: B19 is standing in an offside position. B12 kicks the ball forward but the ball deflects off A11 to B19. B19 should be:
O1: Penalized for being offside.
O2: Issued a caution for being offside.
O3: Allowed to continue with play so long as B19 passes the ball to B12.
O4: Allowed to continue with play.
openA: Penalized for being offside.

Q: Any delayed, excessive or prolonged act(s) by which a player(s) attempts to focus attention upon himself/herself and/or prohibits a timely restart of the game, shall be issued what card?
O1: Yellow/Red Combination
O2: Blue Card Only
O3: Red Card Only
O4: Yellow Card Only
openA: Yellow/Red Combination

Q: Player A of the attacking team is clearly in an offside position when her teammate delivers the ball to her with a throw-in. She collects the ball and kicks it into the goal. The referee 12 should:
O1: Award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Award a goal to Team A.
O3: Award a re-take to Team A.
O4: Award a goal kick to Team B.
openA: Award a goal to Team A.

Q: A3 receives the ball directly from a corner kick taken by A5, while A3 is standing in an offside position. A3 should be:
O1: Issued a verbal warning for being in an offside position
O2: Cautioned and retake the corner kick
O3: Cautioned and award an indirect free kick to the opposing team
O4: Allowed to continue with play
openA: Allowed to continue with play

Q: If during a penalty kick the ball enters the goal and there is a violation by the attacking team, the restart is:
O1: Goal kick.
O2: Retake.
O3: Indirect free kick.
O4: Corner Kick.
openA: Retake.

Q: A2, in an offside position, receives a goal kick taken by B1. The referee shall:
O1: Penalize Team A for A2 being offside.
O2: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.
O3: Only call offside if a goal is scored.
openA: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.

Q: During the game, the referee notices that B30 has tape on her ear lobes. Closer observation indicates that there are earrings underneath the tape. The referee should:
O1: Wait until the next stoppage; and since this is the first caution for illegal equipment, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O2: Wait until the next stoppage, feel B30s ear lobes to check for earrings under the tape and, if so, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O3: Since the referee did not notice the tape before the game, the referee should take no action.
O4: Stop the game, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
openA: Wait until the next stoppage; and since this is the first caution for illegal equipment, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.

Q: Team Bs head coach was cautioned earlier in the game after the referee discovered B5 was wearing an earring while playing in the game. Twenty-seven minutes later, the referee
O2: discovers that B1 is not wearing shinguards.
O3: Since Team B has already been cautioned for an illegally equipped player, the referee may ignore the absence of shinguards on B1.
O4: B1 is cautioned for being illegally equipped. She is required to leave the field and, as the goalkeeper, must be replaced by either a substitute or a field player.
openA: B1 is cautioned for being illegally equipped. She is required to leave the field and, as the goalkeeper, must be replaced by either a substitute or a field player.

Q: Player As throw-in lands completely outside the touchline, without having broken the plane of the touchline, and bounds into the field of play.
O1: The referee awards a throw-in to Team B.
O2: The referee issues a team caution for delay of game.
O3: The referee orders a re-throw by Team A since the ball never was put into play.
O4: The referee allows play to continue.
openA: The referee orders a re-throw by Team A since the ball never was put into play.

Q: The referee inadvertently sounds the whistle.
O1: play is restarted with free kick to the team that had possession when the whistle was blown.
O2: The referee should do nothing and allow play to continue.
O3: The referee stops play and awards a dropped ball regardless of possession.
O4: Realizing the error, the referee verbally directs "play on" to the players to continue play.
openA: play is restarted with a dropped ball

Q: B17 is being replaced on a legal substitution opportunity for her team. What should happen next?
O1: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, is beckoned onto the field by the referee.
O2: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, takes her position on the field.
O3: B17 is considered to still be a player until she has left the field and the game has been restarted.
O4: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, steps onto the field.
openA: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, is beckoned onto the field by the referee.

Q: A player that commits a second violation of misconduct shall be issued a second caution (blue card), shall be disqualified (ejected) from further participation in the game
O2: replaced on the field by a substitute.
O3: TRUE
O4: FALSE because there's no blue card in soccer.
openA: FALSE

Q: A player (other than a goalkeeper within his/her own penalty area) who deliberately handles the ball, attempting to prevent a goal, and the goal is not scored shall be issued what card?
O1: Red Card Only
O2: Blue Card Only
O3: Yellow Card Only
O4: Yellow/Red Combination
openA: Red Card Only

Q: Which of these is true about taunting?
O1: It is not required that the player be disqualified.
O2: Taunting is a misconduct and requires that the offending player be disqualified.
O3: If it is directed at a teammate, it requires no action.
O4: Taunting is a misconduct and requires a caution to the offender.
openA: It is not required that the player be disqualified.

Q: At the taking of a tie-breaking kick from the penalty mark, goalkeeper A1 deflects the kicked ball. As he celebrates, the balls momentum causes it to strike the ground and spin into 24 the goal. The referee should:
O1: Allow the goal.
O2: Have the kicker retake the kick.
O3: Allow the goal and caution the goalkeeper for the celebration.
O4: Disallow the goal as it happened after the goalkeeper's initial touch.
openA: Allow the goal.

Q: The official signal for a goal scored is:
O1: Raising both hands above the head.
O2: Blowing the whistle.
O3: Stopping the clock.
O4: Stopping the clock and pointing to the center of the field.
openA: Stopping the clock and pointing to the center of the field.

Q: When inspecting the game balls, the official determines that the home team has only one satisfactory game ball. The official may choose two additional game balls offered by the
O1: a disqualified ball from the home team.
O2: opposing team.
openA: opposing team.

Q: The ball has gone out for a throw-in by Team A. While A9 is retrieving the ball, the Team A coach says Sub ref! and instructs A5, who is sitting on the bench, to enter the game for 27 A13. What should be the referee's response?
O1: Allow A5 to enter the game during this dead ball.
O2: Only allow Team B substitutes to enter.
O3: Not allow the substitution since player A5 had not reported to the scorer or official area prior to the dead ball.
O4: None of the presented answers are correct.
openA: Not allow the substitution since player A5 had not reported to the scorer or official area prior to the dead ball.

Q: On a throw-in, the ball is in play:
O1: When it leaves the hands of the thrower and breaks the plane of the touchline.
O2: When it touches a second player.
O3: When it touches the playing surface.
O4: When it leaves the hands of the thrower.
openA: When it leaves the hands of the thrower and breaks the plane of the touchline.

Q: Team A is winning and repeatedly substitutes to consume time. The official should:
O1: Take no action as subbing is allowed.
O2: Immediately caution the coach.
O3: Order the timer to stop the clock and notify the offending team's coach that continuing to substitute in this manner will be considered unsporting conduct.
O4: Take no action but write up the incident in his or her game report.
openA: Order the timer to stop the clock and notify the offending team's coach that continuing to substitute in this manner will be considered unsporting conduct.

Q: The referee has awarded Team B a penalty kick. As B4 runs toward the ball to take the kick, A5 enters the penalty area before B4 kicks the ball. The referee should:
O1: Allow the play to continue and award a goal kick if the kick by B4 goes untouched over the goal.
O2: Allow the play to continue and award a corner kick if the kick by B4 is played by the goalkeeper who pushes the ball over the goal line outside of the goal.
O3: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal.
O4: Blow the whistle as soon as A enters the penalty area.
openA: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal.

Q: During play, a field player is injured and removed from the field.
O1: The team may not substitute an unlimited number of players.
O2: the team must replace the injured field player.
O3: The team may only replace the injured player.
O4: The team may substitute an unlimited number of players.
openA: The team may not substitute an unlimited number of players.

Q: An unlimited number of players may be substituted from the bench in which of the following situations:
O1: When a player is cautioned.
O2: At the start of the second period.
O3: When a goal is scored.
O4: When the referee is informed before the match
openA: When the referee is informed before the match

Q: A12 has been cautioned by the referee for unsporting behavior. While A12 is still on the field and before substitute A9 is beckoned onto the field by the referee, A12 directs insulting again
O1: A12 should be cautioned again for his language.
O2: language to the referee.
O3: A12 has already been cautioned and cannot be shown a second card in this situation.
O4: A12s actions are all part of the cautioning process and the referee should ignore his language.
openA: A12s actions are all part of the cautioning process and the referee should ignore his language.

Q: An identifiable supporter of the home team seated in the designated spectator area is screaming profanities at the nearest assistant referee in disagreement with a decision about 34 offside made by the side referee. The referee should:
O1: Stop play and direct the spectator to leave the facility.
O2: Stop play and request that the home school administration take appropriate action.
O3: Allow play to continue and ignore the supporters language.
O4: Stop play and inform the spectator that the assistant referees decision was correct.
openA: Stop play and request that the home school administration take appropriate action.

Q: Prior to the game, whether the field is unsafe for play and the game should be canceled is the responsibility of:
O1: The visiting coach.
O2: The host coach.
O3: The referee.
O4: The host athletic director.
openA: The host athletic director.

Q: The official time will be kept by a contest official on the field, and if the stadium clock is available, it is unofficial.
O1: FALSE
O2: TRUE
openA: TRUE

Q: The referee observes a foul, but does not penalize it because she perceives an advantage; however, the advantage does not develop.
O1: The referee will stop play caution the player who committed the original foul and re-start with a direct free kick.
O2: The referee will let play continue because advantage was given.
O3: The referee will stop play caution the player who committed the original foul and re-start with an indirect free kick.
O4: The referee shall immediately stop play and penalize the original foul.
openA: The referee will let play continue because advantage was given.

Q: Team A takes a shot on goal, which deflects off the referee and goes across the goal line just to the right of the goal.
O1: The referee will award an indirect kick to Team A.
O2: The referee will award a dropped ball.
O3: The referee shall award a goal kick to Team B.
O4: The referee shall award a corner kick.
openA: The referee shall award a goal kick to Team B.

Q: Team Bs head coach receives a second caution and is disqualified for receiving a second caution. The referee shall:
O1: Immediately display the red card.
O2: Display no card but immediately request the coach to leave the vicinity.
O3: Display the yellow card indicating the subsequent caution immediately followed by a red card.
O4: Display both the yellow and the red card at the same time in the same hand.
openA: Display the yellow card indicating the subsequent caution immediately followed by a red card.

Q: A9 scores a goal to make the score 1-0 with 1:30 left in the game. He runs toward the portion of the spectators dominated by his schools supporters, removes his shirt and waves it
O1: A9 is guilty of unsporting conduct. The referee should caution A9 with a yellow card.
O2: above his head.
O3: A9 is guilty of taunting. The referee should disqualify A9.
O4: A9 is not guilty of an offense. Play should restart with a Team B kickoff.
openA: A9 is guilty of unsporting conduct. The referee should caution A9 with a yellow card.

Q: The referee has awarded Team B a penalty kick. The goalkeeper, A1, stands with his back to the ball. The referee shall:
O1: Require the goalkeeper to face the kicker.
O2: Declare a forfeit.
O3: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.
O4: Suspend the contest until the goalkeeper agrees to face the kicker.
openA: Require the goalkeeper to face the kicker.

Q: During play, A1, the goalkeeper, is injured in a collision with B5, who is also injured. The referee stops play and calls the coach or trainer from both teams onto the field to attend to 42 their players. What should happen next?
O1: Since A1 is the goalkeeper, neither B5 nor A1 are required to leave the field.
O2: Both B5 and A1 must leave the field. B5 may be replaced by substitutes from the bench, and A1 must be replaced by substitutes from the bench.
O3: B5 must leave the field and may be replaced.
O4: A1 must leave the field and may be replaced.
openA: Both B5 and A1 must leave the field. B5 may be replaced by substitutes from the bench, and A1 must be replaced by substitutes from the bench.

Q: B9 runs towards the ball, which is rolling on the ground near the right goal post. A3 faces B9, with the ball behind her, and extends her arms wide to prevent B9 from running past her
O2: to get the ball. A3 does not make physical contact with B9. The ball rolls over the goal line for a goal kick.
O3: A3 is guilty of obstruction. The referee should award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O4: A3 is guilty of pushing. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team B.
openA: A3 is guilty of obstruction. The referee should award an indirect free kick to Team B.

Q: A player who is illegally equipped and whose coach is cautioned for the misconduct:
O1: Must correct the illegal equipment but is not required to leave the field of play.
O2: Must also be cautioned.
O3: Must leave the field of play and may not return until legally equipped.
O4: Must leave the field of play and can return at the next dead ball.
openA: Must leave the field of play and may not return until legally equipped.

Q: Player A2, in taking a penalty kick, approaches the ball and then stops abruptly. The goalkeeper dives to the side. A2 then kicks the ball and scores.
O1: The referee shall award a goal and restart with a kickoff.
O2: The referee shall rule no goal and order the kick to be retaken.
O3: The referee shall not award a goal and restart the game with a goal kick.
O4: The referee shall caution the player for unsporting conduct.
openA: The referee shall caution the player for unsporting conduct.

Q: A player that commits a non-violent foul, attempting to deny an obvious goal-scoring opportunity, and the goal is not scored, shall be issued a (blue card), shall be disqualified
O2: (ejected) from further participation in the game, and shall not be replaced on the field by a substitute.
O3: TRUE
O4: FALSE because there's no blue card in soccer.
openA: TRUE

Q: If on a penalty kick there is a deflection over the goal by the goalkeeper and no violation by either team, the restart is a:
O1: Indirect free kick.
O2: Retake.
O3: Goal Kick.
O4: Corner kick.
openA: Corner kick.

Q: A player that commits an act of taunting (use of word or act to incite or degrade an opposing player, coach, referee or other individual) shall be:
O1: Issued a yellow card
O2: Issued a caution
O3: Issued a red card, disqualified from further participation and shall not be replaced on the field
openA: Issued a caution

Q: An indirect free kick is awarded to Team B. A player from Team A refuses to move the required 10 yards and then kicks the ball away.
O1: The referee shall issue a red card for taunting and award an indirect kick.
O2: The referee directs team B to retake the kick.
O3: A direct free kick should be awarded to Team B.
O4: The referee shall caution the player and award an indirect kick.
openA: The referee shall caution the player and award an indirect kick.

Q: A dark jersey is defined as:
O1: Any color that incorporates black.
O2: Any color that contrasts with white.
O3: Black.
O4: Grey.
openA: Any color that contrasts with white.

Q: Player A deliberately kicks the ball to her goalkeeper within her penalty area. When the goalkeeper touches the ball with her hands, the referee shall award an indirect free kick at the spot of the violation unless the violation occurs in the goal area. [Rule 12-7-3]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Team Bs head coach was cautioned earlier in the game after the referee discovered B5 was wearing an earring while playing in the game. Twenty-seven minutes later, the referee discovers that B1 is not wearing shinguards.
openA: B1 is cautioned for being illegally equipped. She is required to leave the field and, as the goalkeeper, must be replaced by either a substitute or a field player.
O1: The Team B head coach should receive a second caution for an illegally equipped player. The Team B coach is disqualified for receiving a second caution.
O2: B1 is cautioned for being illegally equipped. She is required to leave the field and, as the goalkeeper, must be replaced by either a substitute or a field player.
O3: Both B1 and the Team B head coach should be cautioned.
O4: Since Team B has already been cautioned for an illegally equipped player, the referee may ignore the absence of shinguards on B1.

Q: B17 is wearing a cast that is completely covered and padded with closed-cell, slow-recovery foam padding no less than -inch thick. Before B17 can play, the referee must see a doctors permission slip. [Rule 4-2-1c]
openA: False. B17 is legally equipped.
O1: True
O2: False. B17 is legally equipped.

Q: A9 believes that he has been fouled by B4. The referee allows play to continue. A9 spits at the referee. If the referee stops play immediately, the referee should restart play with an indirect free kick.
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False.

Q: The referee inadvertently sounds the whistle. Realizing the error, the referee verbally directs "play on" to the players to continue play. This is correct procedure. [Rule 9-1-2c]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: B14 takes a shot on goal, with goalkeeper A1 out of position. A3, however, extends her arm into the path of the ball, deflecting it to B9. B9 shoots and the ball enters the goal. [Rule PR 5-3-1 Situation A]
openA: The referee should allow the goal and caution A3 for unsporting conduct.
O1: The referee should award Team B a penalty kick and caution A3 for unsporting conduct.
O2: The referee should award Team B a penalty kick and disqualify A3 for serious foul play.
O3: The referee should allow the goal and caution A3 for unsporting conduct.
O4: The referee should allow the goal and disqualify A3 for serious foul play.

Q: A throw-in by Player A goes directly to her own goalkeeper, who catches the ball with her hands. The referee should allow play to continue. [Rule 12-7-4]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: At the taking of a tie-breaking kick from the penalty mark, goalkeeper A1 deflects the kicked ball. As he celebrates, the balls momentum causes it to strike the ground and spin into the goal. Count the kick as a goal. [Rule PR 14.1.6 Situation (b)]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: The home school has provided an official timer whose wristwatch is not visible to table officials. This complies with the rules. [Rule 6-2-2]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Bench Player A leaves the team area and enters the field where a fight is in progress. Although Player A did not participate in the fight, he/she should still be disqualified. [Rule 12-8-2g]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: An indirect free kick is awarded to Team B. A player from Team A refuses to move the required 10 yards and then kicks the ball away. A direct free kick should be awarded to Team B. [Rule 13-3-1 Penalty]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Prior to the game, the host athletic director determines the field is unsafe for play and cancels the game despite the protests of the coaches and officials. This is correct procedure. [Rule 1-7]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A8 is dribbling toward goal on a breakaway. The goalkeeper, B1, comes out of the goal area in an attempt to stop A8. A8 kicks the ball past B1 and attempts to run around B1, who is now on the ground. B1 reaches up with his hand and pulls down A8 as he attempts to run past.
openA: B1 is guilty of holding. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team A if he cannot apply advantage and disqualify B1 for serious foul play.
O1: B1 is guilty of holding. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team A.
O2: B1 is guilty of holding. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team A and disqualify B1 for serious foul play.
O3: B1 is guilty of holding. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team A if he cannot apply advantage and disqualify B1 for serious foul play.
O4: There is no offense. The referee should allow play to continue.

Q: The substitute for a player who leaves the field due to bleeding is permitted to take the penalty kick. [Rule 3-3-3d(2)]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Prior to the game, a player is found to be wearing shinguards that do not contain the NOCSAE seal. The player is allowed to participate with the shinguards. This is proper procedure. [Rule 4-1-1]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A9 scores a goal to make the score 1-0 with 1:30 left in the game. He runs toward the portion of the spectators dominated by his schools supporters, removes his shirt and waves it above his head. [Rule 12-8-1f(12) and 12.8.1 Situation B (c)]
openA: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee should caution A9.
O1: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee should caution A9.
O2: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee should disqualify A9.
O3: A9 is guilty of taunting. The referee should disqualify A9.
O4: A9 is not guilty of an offense. Play should restart with a Team B kickoff.

Q: Team A takes a shot on goal, which deflects off the referee and goes across the goal line just to the right of the goal. The referee shall award a goal kick to Team B. [Rule 16-1-1; 9-1-2b]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: During their inspection of the field, the referees note that the field has multiple lines of different colors, some of which overlap each other. This is permitted by rule. [Rule 1-2-1]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: Before the game begins, the head referee must verify with each coach that his/her players are legally and properly equipped for the game. [Rule 4-3; 5-5-2d(4)]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: During the game, the referee hears the home team's head coach using a bull horn to instruct her players on the far side of the field. [Rule 12-8-1e]
openA: This is not permitted.
O1: This is permitted.
O2: This is not permitted.

Q: The referee terminates a game with 10 minutes remaining in the first half and Team B leading by a score of 2-0 because of misbehavior by the Team B coach. The referee should declare Team A the winner. [Rule PR 7.1.3 Situation (b)]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: The referee awards a direct free kick to Team B, 25 yards from the Team A goal. The goalkeeper, A1, who is the Team A captain, runs to the referee, who is still at the spot of the foul, to argue that the foul should obviously be against the Team B player. The referee should caution A1 for dissent. [Rule 12-8-1c]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False. The referee should not caution A1 since A1 is the captain and has a right to address the referee on matters of interpretation.

Q: B10 is apparently injured during the run of play. The referee has stopped play and summoned the Team B trainer onto the field of play. [Rule PR 3.3.3 SITUATION I]
openA: Both coaches may give their teams coaching instruction.
O1: Neither coach may give coaching instruction to his or her players during the injury stoppage.
O2: The Team A coach may give instruction to the Team A players but the Team B coach must only attend to the injured player.
O3: The Team B coach may only give instructions to the substitute for B10.
O4: Both coaches may give their teams coaching instruction.

Q: The first time a player enters the game wearing illegal equipment, the players coach shall be cautioned (yellow card). [Rule 4-3]
openA: False
O1: True
O2: False

Q: The visiting team, whose school colors are red and black, is wearing red socks. The visiting team No. 3 has applied several layers of red tape to his/her socks, both above and below the shinguards. [Rule 4-1-1c]
openA: This is permitted.
O1: This is permitted.
O2: This is not permitted.

Q: Player A2, in taking a penalty kick, approaches the ball and then stops abruptly. The goalkeeper dives to the side. A2 then kicks the ball and scores. The referee shall rule no goal and order the kick to be retaken. [Rule 14-1-4; PR 14.1.4 Situation B]
openA: True
O1: True
O2: False

Q: A24 has been penalized for offside. A24 was standing at the penalty mark when the ball was kicked to him by a teammate. Standing at the top of the penalty area when the ball was received.
openA: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the penalty mark.
O1: Team B restarts with a direct free kick from the penalty mark.
O2: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the penalty mark.
O3: Team B restarts with a direct free kick from the top of the penalty area.
O4: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the top of the penalty area

Q: The visiting coach does not have a roster with her at the game site. [Rule 3-1-3]
openA: The game may not begin until the coach provides a roster.
