Q: An official arrives at the field and is told by the head referee that he/she will be using headsets for communications during the match. No action concerning the use of electronic communication equipment by referees has been taken by the respective state association. The official should:
openA: Use the equipment as it has not been prohibited by the state association. 5-1-3f
O1: Refuse to use such equipment as it is illegal.
O2: Use the equipment as directed but report the head referee to the state association for using illegal communication equipment.
O3: Use the equipment as it has not been prohibited by the state association.
O4: Only use the equipment if both coaches agree.

Q: A team with fewer than 11 players, but at least 7 players, may have an additional player enter the game:
openA: At the next dead ball. 3-3-8
O1: At the next substitution opportunity for the late arriving player.
O2: At the next dead ball.
O3: During the run of play.
O4: Only at the beginning of the next half.

Q: A24 has been penalized for offside. A24 was standing at the penalty mark when the ball was kicked to him by a teammate. The second-last defender was standing at the top of the penalty area when the ball was received by A24.
openA: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the penalty mark. 11.1.1; 11.1.4
O1: Team B restarts with a direct free kick from the penalty mark.
O2: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the penalty mark.
O3: Team B restarts with a direct free kick from the top of the penalty area.
O4: Team B restarts with an indirect free kick from the top of the penalty area.

Q: Player A2 is in an offside position when player A3 takes a shot on goal which the goalkeeper attempts to save and rebounds from the goalkeeper to A2. A2 shoots and scores. Ruling:
openA: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to Team B. 11-1-4
O1: Disallow the goal and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Allow the goal.
O3: Disallow the goal and award a goal kick to Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal and award a penalty kick to Team A.

Q: A9 scores a goal to make the score 1-0 with 1:30 left in the game. He runs toward the portion of the spectators dominated by his schools supporters, removes his shirt and waves it above his head.
openA: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee 12-8-1f(12), 12-8-1 should caution A9. SITUATION B (c)
O1: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee should caution A9.
O2: A9 is guilty of an excessive act that focuses attention on himself. The referee should disqualify A9.
O3: A9 is guilty of taunting. The referee should disqualify A9.
O4: A9 is not guilty of an offense. Play should restart with a Team B kickoff. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: Defender B7 handles the ball inside the penalty area, deflecting it to A3, who scores. What is the correct procedure:
openA: The referee should allow the goal, caution B7 and restart with a kickoff for 12-8-1f(13) Team B.
O1: The referee should disallow the goal, caution B7 and award a penalty kick to Team A.
O2: The referee should allow the goal, disqualify B7 and restart with a kickoff for Team B.
O3: The referee should not allow the goal, disqualify B7 and award a penalty kick to Team A.
O4: The referee should allow the goal, caution B7 and restart with a kickoff for Team B.

Q: Goalkeeper B1 deflects a hard shot. B1 bends over and picks up the ball before it is touched by an opposing player in the penalty area. The referee should award an indirect kick to Team A, which is:
openA: Not the correct call as the referee should allow play to continue. 12-7-2
O1: The correct call.
O2: Not the correct call as the referee should allow play to continue.
O3: Not the correct call as a penalty kick should be awarded.
O4: Not the correct call as a drop ball should be awarded.

Q: Player B4 is disqualified for receiving a second caution. The referee should:
openA: Show a yellow card followed by a red card and notify both coaches of the 12-8-2 SITUATION I nature of the misconduct.
O1: Allow B12 to substitute for B4 as soon as B4 leaves the field.
O2: Display a red and yellow card simultaneously.
O3: Show only a red card and not a yellow card.
O4: Show a yellow card followed by a red card and notify both coaches of the nature of the misconduct.

Q: The head coach of Team A reaches onto the field to knock down a mid-air pass to B8, who is unmarked but still 45 yards away from the goal.
openA: The coach should be cautioned for unsporting conduct, and game restarted 12-8-1f(1), 12-8-1f(7) with a direct free kick.
O1: The coach should be cautioned for unsporting conduct, and game restarted with a direct free kick.
O2: The coach should be dismissed for failing to conduct himself in a responsible manner.
O3: The coachs behavior is outside interference and the referee should restart play with a drop ball.
O4: There is no offense and play should continue.

Q: The referee has awarded Team B a penalty kick. As B4 runs toward the ball to take the kick, A5 enters the penalty area before B4 kicks the ball. The referee should:
openA: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal. 14-1-2 PENALTY
O1: Blow the whistle as soon as A enters the penalty area.
O2: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal.
O3: Allow the play to continue and award a goal kick if the kick by B4 goes untouched over the goal.
O4: Allow the play to continue and award a corner kick if the kick by B4 is played by the goalkeeper who pushes the ball over the goal line outside of the goal.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, A3 uses a feint to one direction but does not interrupt the approach to the ball. The ball enters the goal. The referee should:
openA: Allow the goal and restart with kickoff by the defending team. 14-1-4
O1: Allow the goal and restart with kickoff by the defending team.
O2: Disallow the goal and retake the kick.
O3: Disallow the goal and restart with an indirect kick by Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal, caution A7 for unsporting play and restart with an indirect kick by Team B. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: Team B's goalkeeper is apparently injured. The referee has stopped play and summoned the Team B trainer onto the field of play. Team B has no available substitutes.
openA: O2 and O3.
O1: Team B can play without a goalkeeper until the injured player returns.
O2: Team B goalkeeper must leave the field.
O3: A substitute goalkeeper must be identified.
O4: O2 and O3.

Q: During the pregame warm-up, the referee observes A4 wearing a tight-fitting, bucket-style cloth hat.
openA: This is permitted for a medical/cosmetic reason with state association 4-2-11 approval.
O1: This is permitted for a medical/cosmetic reason with state association approval.
O2: Hat color must match the predominant color of the jersey.
O3: This is permitted if a physician's statement by a licensed medical physician is available on site.
O4: This is not permitted.

Q: Prior to the game, the referee is informed that player B4 must maintain a covered head for religious reasons.
openA: B4 is wearing a hijab. 4-2-10
O1: B4 is wearing a baseball cap.
O2: B4 is wearing a leather doo rag.
O3: B4 is wearing a hijab.
O4: B4 is wearing a bandanna covering the head which is knotted in back.

Q: Visiting Team B is wearing white jerseys and socks. B1 is wearing a black long-sleeve undershirt, B2 is wearing black tights, and B3 is wearing a black arm sleeve.
openA: Illegal. Visible apparel does not match
O1: B3 is wearing illegal equipment as arm sleeves are not allowed.
O2: This is legal.
O3: Illegal. Visible apparel does not match the predominant color of the uniform.
O4: Illegal as visible undergarments are not all alike.

Q: During an attack by Team A, A4 is laying injured on the ground in an offside position. A3 scores an apparent goal while A4 is in the offside position.
openA: Allow the goal as A4 was not involved in active play. 11-1-4
O1: Disallow the goal and penalize A4 for being offside.
O2: Disallow the goal and award a goal kick to Team B.
O3: Allow the goal, but caution A4 for an unsporting act.
O4: Allow the goal as A4 was not involved in active play.

Q: A4 is in an offside position when teammate A6 passes the ball to A4. A4 runs from the offside position into his/her own half of the field and receives the ball in his/her defensive half.
openA: A4 is penalized for offside. Award an indirect kick to B at the spot of the 11-1-4 infraction.
O1: Allow play to continue as A4 is in his/her own half of the field.
O2: A4 is penalized for offside. Award an indirect kick to B at the spot of the infraction.
O3: A4 is penalized for offside. Award an indirect kick to B at the spot where A6 made the pass.
O4: Allow play to continue as A4 was not involved in active play when the pass was made. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: A2, in the penalty area, is advancing the ball toward the opponent's goal with an obvious goal-scoring opportunity. B3, who is attempting to play the ball, fouls A2, who does not score a goal.
openA: Award Team A a penalty kick and caution B3 for denying an obvious goal- 12-8-1(f)15 scoring opportunity.
O1: Award Team A a penalty kick and disqualify B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.
O2: Award Team A a penalty kick.
O3: Award Team A a penalty kick and caution B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.
O4: Award Team A a corner kick.

Q: A2 is advancing the ball toward the opponent's goal with an obvious goal-scoring opportunity. B3, who is attempting to play the ball, fouls A2, who is outside the penalty area and does not score a goal.
openA: Award Team A a direct kick and disqualify B3 for denying an obvious goal- 12-8-2d(3) scoring opportunity.
O1: Award Team A a penalty kick and disqualify B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.
O2: Award Team A a penalty kick and caution B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.
O3: Award Team A a direct kick and caution B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.
O4: Award Team A a direct kick and disqualify B3 for denying an obvious goal-scoring opportunity.

Q: During active play, Team B's coach enters the playing field to argue a call with the official, but does not interfere with active play.
openA: Resume play with a drop ball.
O1: Award Team A a direct kick from the point of the infraction.
O2: Award Team A an indirect kick from the point of the infraction.
O3: Resume play with a drop ball.
O4: Award Team A an indirect kick from where the ball was when the referee stopped play.

Q: During active play, Substitute/Bench Player B12 mistakenly thinks the ball has gone out of bounds and kicks the ball toward a teammate who is in play.
openA: Award Team A a direct kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball and 13-2-1j caution B12.
O1: Award Team A a direct kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball and caution B12.
O2: Award Team A an indirect kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball.
O3: Resume play with a drop ball at the point where B12 kicked the ball.
O4: Allow play to continue with no stoppage.

Q: If bench personnel are cautioned or disqualified:
openA: Substitutions from either team who have checked-in prior to the 3-3-3c, e; 3-4-1d caution/disqualification may enter the game.
O1: Substitutions may be made from the bench.
O2: Substitutions from the bench of the non-offending team may enter the game.
O3: Substitutions from either bench may enter the game.
O4: Substitutions from either team who have checked-in prior to the caution/disqualification may enter the game.

Q: In the last five minutes of a game, Team A is in the lead and requests a substitution.
openA: Allow the substitution and the clock is not stopped.
O1: Make Team A play short.
O2: Allow the substitution and the clock is not stopped.
O3: Stop the clock for the substitution.
O4: Caution the coach for unsporting behavior. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: The visiting coach does not have a roster with her at the game site.
openA: The game may not begin until the coach provides a roster. 3-1-3
O1: The game may not begin until the coach provides a roster.
O2: The game may begin if the coach promises to provide a roster by the end of the game.
O3: The game may begin if the coach promises to provide a roster by halftime.
O4: The game may begin but the referee should remind the coach that a roster is required for future games.

Q: B17 is wearing a cast that is completely covered and padded with closed-cell, slow-recovery foam padding no less than -inch thick. The referee should:
openA: Allow B17 to play as this is permitted by rule. 4-2-1c
O1: Verify B17 has a doctor's permission slip before allowing B17 to play.
O2: Allow B17 to play as this is permitted by rule.
O3: Request a certified athletic trainer or physician inspect and approve the cast and padding prior to B17 being allowed to play.
O4: Not permit B17 to play.

Q: Goalkeepers are required to:
openA: Have a 6-inch number on the back and no number on the front of their jersey.
O1: Have a 6-inch number on the back and front of their jersey.
O2: Have a 6-inch number on the back and a 4-inch number on the front of their jersey, pants or shorts.
O3: Have a 6-inch number on the back and no number on the front of their jersey.
O4: Have no numbers on their jersey.

Q: Player A from the visiting team enters the game wearing two different colored socks.
openA: Both socks must be the same color. 4-1-1b, 4-3
O1: This is permitted.
O2: Both socks must be the same color.
O3: This is permitted if the whole team is wearing two different colored socks.
O4: This is permitted as long as the socks contrast with the home team's white socks.

Q: The first time in a game that a player from Team B is found to be wearing illegal equipment, the coach of Team B is to be cautioned.
openA: Caution the head coach. 4-3
O1: Caution the head coach.
O2: The player is to be cautioned.
O3: Take no action, but write up the player in the game report.
O4: Allow the player to start, stop play and caution the player for wearing illegal equipment.

Q: While waiting for a corner kick to be taken by Team B, with Team A ahead, 2-1, in the second half, goalkeeper A1 pushes B7 to the ground from behind. B7 gets up and punches A1 in the face. Both teams then engage in a general brawl. After the fighting has ceased, the referee feels that because of the fight, further disorder will result and because of this, terminates the game.
openA: The referee has authority to terminate the game but does not have authority 5-3-1i, 5-3-2e, 5-3-2 to declare either team the winner. SITUATION B
O1: If both teams have seven eligible players after the referee has disqualified the appropriate players, the game must be restarted.
O2: The referee has authority to terminate the game and declare Team B the winner since the Team A player began the fight.
O3: The referee has authority to terminate the game. The 2-1 score for Team A stands as the official score since more than half the game was played.
O4: The referee has authority to terminate the game but does not have authority to declare either team the winner. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: Team A has a kickoff in the first half of play. Player A1 kicks the ball backward to Player A2. The official should:
openA: Allow play to continue. 8-1-3
O1: Order the kick to be retaken.
O2: Award a direct free kick to Team B.
O3: Require Team A to retake the kickoff.
O4: Allow play to continue.

Q: B9 runs towards the ball, which is rolling on the ground near the right goal post. A3 faces B9, with the ball behind her, and extends her arms wide to prevent B9 from running past her to get the ball. A3 does not make physical contact with B9. The ball rolls over the goal line for a goal kick.
openA: There is no offense, and a goal kick should be awarded.
O1: A3 is guilty of pushing. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team B.
O2: A3 is guilty of pushing. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team B and disqualify A3 for serious foul play.
O3: A3 is guilty of obstruction. The referee should award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O4: There is no offense, and a goal kick should be awarded.

Q: The referee awards a direct free kick to Team B, 25 yards from the Team A goal. The goalkeeper, A1, who is the Team A captain, runs to the referee, who is at the spot of the foul, to argue that the foul should obviously be against the Team B player. The referee should:
openA: caution A1 for dissent. 12-8-1c
O1: allow A1 to speak to him, then ask him to return to his position.
O2: caution A1 for dissent.
O3: caution A4 for dissent as the captain has special privileges.
O4: allow play to continue.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, A3 uses a feint to one direction and comes to a complete stop and then kicks the ball into the goal. The referee should:
openA: Disallow the goal and retake the kick. 14-1-4
O1: Allow the goal and restart with kickoff by team.
O2: Disallow the goal and retake the kick.
O3: Disallow the goal and restart with an indirect kick for Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal, caution A7 for unsporting play and restart with an indirect kick for Team B.

Q: Team A has been awarded an indirect free kick 22 yards from the Team B goal. Four Team A players are standing near the ball. A8 taps the top of the ball with his foot and the ball does not move. A5 then kicks the ball, which enters the Team B goal without being touched by any other player.
openA: Award a goal kick to the defending team. 13-3-2, 18-1-1o
O1: Award a goal.
O2: Have Team A retake the kick.
O3: Award a goal kick to the defending team.
O4: Caution Player A8 for unsporting behavior.

Q: In the 68th minute, with the score 2-1 for Team A, a confrontation between A5 and B11 escalates into a mass brawl. The referee and coaches eventually end the fight. In the opinion of the referee, A5 started the fight.
openA: The referee may terminate the game and shall report all conditions regarding 5-3-2e, 5.3.2 SITUATION B the incident to the proper authorities in writing.
O1: The referee may terminate the game and declare Team B the winner.
O2: The referee may terminate the game and declare Team A the winner.
O3: The referee may terminate the game and declare the game no contest.
O4: The referee may terminate the game and shall report all conditions regarding the incident to the proper authorities in writing. E. The referee may not terminate the game and should restart with a direct free kick for Team B. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: The game officials are observed using flags with buzzer/beeper capabilities during a match. The use of these flags is:
openA: Allowed unless the state association has expressly prohibited such 5-1-3f equipment.
O1: Prohibited.
O2: Permitted in all cases.
O3: Allowed unless the state association has expressly prohibited such equipment.
O4: Allowed only if both coaches agree.

Q: The jurisdiction of the officials shall begin:
openA: On arrival at the field of play and its immediate surroundings. 5-1-2
O1: No later than 15 minutes prior to the start of the game.
O2: On arrival at the field of play and its immediate surroundings.
O3: As soon as the game starts.
O4: As soon as the referee enters the field of play.

Q: Goalkeeper A1 is waiting for a high ball to come down in his vicinity. As it reaches him and seeing B9 approaching, he jumps up for the ball with both hands extended. B9 comes running into the area and jumps up for the ball, attempting to head it into the goal. A1 and B9 collide, causing both to fall to the ground.
openA: Neither A1 nor B9 is guilty of any offense. The referee should allow play to 12.4.4 SITUATION A(a) continue, unless one or both players are injured.
O1: A1 is guilty of obstruction. The referee should award Team B an indirect free kick.
O2: B9 is guilty of an illegal charge. The referee should award Team A an indirect free kick.
O3: B9 is guilty of dangerous play. The referee should award Team A an indirect free kick.
O4: Neither A1 nor B9 is guilty of any offense. The referee should allow play to continue, unless one or both players are injured.

Q: During active play, Team B's coach enters the playing field to argue a call with the official and interferes with active play.
openA: Award Team A a direct kick from the point of the infraction. 13-2-1j
O1: Award Team A a direct kick from the point of the infraction.
O2: Award Team A an indirect kick from the point of the infraction.
O3: Resume play with a drop ball.
O4: Award Team A an indirect kick from where the ball was when the referee stopped play.

Q: While A10 is dribbling toward the goal, a substitute in the bench area, B17, throws a water bottle at A5, striking him in the head. The referee stops play, determines that A5 is able to continue to play and disqualifies B17.
openA: The game must be restarted with an indirect free kick by Team A from the 13-2-3b location of the ball at the time A5 was struck.
O1: The game must be restarted with a direct free kick by Team A from the spot where A5 was struck.
O2: The game must be restarted with an indirect free kick by Team A from the spot where A5 was struck.
O3: The game must be restarted with a direct free kick by Team A from the location of the ball at the time A5 was struck.
O4: The game must be restarted with an indirect free kick by Team A from the location of the ball at the time A5 was struck.

Q: The referee awards a throw-in to Team A. A 14 takes the throw, but the ball hits the ground outside the touchline before entering the field. The referee should:
openA: Allow Team A to retake the throw.
O1: Allow play to continue, ball is in play.
O2: Allow Team A to retake the throw.
O3: Allow the throw-in to Team B from the same location.
O4: Administer a drop ball at the spot where the ball touched the ground. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: On a throw-in, the ball is in play:
openA: When it leaves the hands of the thrower and breaks the plane of the 15-1-4 touchline.
O1: When it leaves the hands of the thrower.
O2: When it touches the playing surface.
O3: When it leaves the hands of the thrower and breaks the plane of the touchline.
O4: When it touches a second player.

Q: Before a tie-breaker penalty-kick procedure conducted under the NFHS Sample Tie-Breaking Procedure, Team B had only 10 players on the field at the end of overtime due to a red card given in the second overtime to B5. Team A had 11 players on the field at the end of overtime.
openA: Team B can select any five players from its roster, other than B5, to take its SAMPLE TIE-BREAKING first five kicks of the penalty kick procedure. Team A can select any five PROCEDURE A.3.b players from its roster.
O1: Team B may have only the 10 players on the field at the end of overtime participate in the penalty-kick procedure. Team A must select one of its players to not participate in the penalty-kick procedure. (reduce to equate.)
O2: Team B may have only the 10 players on the field at the end of overtime participate in the penalty-kick procedure. Team A does not have to reduce to equate under the NFHS procedure.
O3: Team B can select any five players from its roster to take the first five kicks of the penalty-kick procedure. Team A can also select any five players from its roster.
O4: Team B can select any five players from its roster, other than B5, to take its first five kicks of the penalty kick procedure. Team A can select any five players from its roster.

Q: A tooth and mouth protector is allowed but not mandatory. It is recommended that the protector be:
openA: All of the above. 4-2-7 NOTES
O1: Properly fitted.
O2: Constructed from a model made of the individuals teeth.
O3: A readily visible color.
O4: All of the above.

Q: During their inspection of the field, the referees note that the portable goals are not secured, anchored or counterweighted. The home teams head coach says that this is the first time all year that this has been considered a problem. What should be the referee's response?
openA: The goals must be secured, anchored or counterweighted before the game 1.4.1 SITUATION B may begin.
O1: The goals must be secured, anchored or counterweighted before the game may begin.
O2: The game may begin without the goals being secured, anchored or counterweighted, but the referees must report this to the appropriate authority.
O3: The game may begin without the goals being secured, anchored or counterweighted but the referees should report this to the home teams head coach and ask that the goals be properly secured for subsequent games.
O4: Since previous referees have allowed games to be played at this site without the goals being secured, anchored or counterweighted, the referees should take no further action.

Q: A dark jersey is defined as:
openA: Any color that contrasts with white. 4-1-1a
O1: Black.
O2: Any color other than white.
O3: Any color that contrasts with white.
O4: Any color that incorporates black. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: After Team A scores a goal, the assistant referee hears the Team A head coach calling one of his players, A15, off the field. The assistant referee counts the Team A players now on the field and realizes that Team A had 12 players on the field when the goal was scored. The assistant referee notifies the referee of this. The referee should:
openA: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a goal kick taken by Team B. 3-1-1 SITUATION B(a), 12- 8-1a
O1: Allow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a kickoff by Team B.
O2: Allow the goal and restart with a kickoff by Team B, with no caution to A15.
O3: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a kickoff by Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a goal kick taken by Team B.

Q: Which statement does not allow an official to caution or disqualify a player?
openA: After the game has ended and the official has left the jurisdiction of the field 5-1-2 of play and its immediate surroundings.
O1: During the pregame introduction of players because the game has not started.
O2: During an injury stoppage.
O3: When the clock has stopped following a scored goal.
O4: After the game has ended and the official has left the jurisdiction of the field of play and its immediate surroundings.

Q: The referees are wearing yellow jerseys. The home team is wearing yellow jerseys. The referee shall:
openA: Change to a jersey of a color distinct from the field players. 5-1-3a
O1: Change to a jersey of a color distinct from the field players.
O2: Require the away team to change to a different color jersey.
O3: Begin the contest as this is permitted by rule.
O4: Consult with the head coaches of each team to see if they have an objection.

Q: The game officials are observed using headset communication equipment to speak with each other during a match. The use of this equipment is:
openA: Allowed unless the state association has prohibited such equipment. 5-1-3f
O1: Prohibited.
O2: Permitted in all cases.
O3: Allowed unless the state association has prohibited such equipment.
O4: Allowed only if both coaches agree.

Q: Since there is no visible clock available at the game site, the referee shall:
openA: Keep the official time on his or her watch and shall stop and start the watch at 5-3-2f, 6-2-1, 6-2-3a the times specified in Rule 6-2-3a.
O1: Not begin the contest until a visible clock is made available.
O2: Keep the official time on his or her watch and shall stop and start the watch at the times specified in Rule 6-2-3a.
O3: Keep the official time on his or her watch and add time to the end of each period as needed.
O4: Have the home team's coach keep the official time on the bench.

Q: During the course of play near the touchline, the official notes that Player A is running outside the field of play and is playing the ball, which is inside the field of play.
openA: The ball continues to be in play. 9-1-2e
O1: The referee shall award an indirect kick for the violation.
O2: The ball continues to be in play.
O3: The referee shall stop play and give the ball back to Team A for a throw-in.
O4: The referee shall award a throw-in to Team B. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: A pass by A2 to A3 strikes the referee who is standing in the penalty area. The ball remains on the field of play and is controlled by B2. What is the appropriate restart?
openA: Drop ball to the team that last touched the ball
O1: Indirect free kick.
O2: Throw-in.
O3: Drop ball to the team that last touched the ball prior to hitting the referee.
O4: Drop ball to the defending goalkeeper.

Q: Which statement results in a goal?
openA: During a goal kick, Goalkeeper A1 takes the kick and the ball deflects off a 10-1-1 player from his/her own team who was inside the penalty area and the ball deflects into the goal.
O1: During a goal kick, Goalkeeper A1 takes the kick and the ball deflects off a player from Team B who was inside the penalty area before the ball moved and the ball deflects into the goal.
O2: Goalkeeper A1 catches a shot on goal by Team B. In preparing to throw the ball to a teammate, Goalkeeper A slips and drops the ball which lands on the goal line between the goalposts before picking the ball up again.
O3: During a goal kick, Goalkeeper A1 takes the kick and the ball deflects off a player from his/her own team who was inside the penalty area and the ball deflects into the goal.
O4: Goalkeeper A1 slips when taking a goal kick and mis-hits the ball which lands entirely across the goal line and between the goalposts.

Q: Player A of the attacking team is clearly in an offside position when her teammate delivers the ball to her with a throw- in. She collects the ball and kicks it into the goal. The referee should:
openA: Award a goal to Team A. 11-1-2
O1: Award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Award a goal to Team A.
O3: Award a goal kick to Team B.
O4: Award a re-take to Team A.

Q: A player shall be disqualified (red card) for:
openA: All of the above. 12-8-2d
O1: Disproportionate and unnecessary force against an opponent while playing the ball.
O2: Deliberately handling the ball (other than the goalkeeper) attempting to prevent a goal and the goal is not scored.
O3: Committing a foul, attempting to deny an obvious goal-scoring opportunity, and the goal is not scored.
O4: All of the above.

Q: A12 has been cautioned by the referee for unsporting behavior. While A12 is still on the field and before substitute A9 is beckoned onto the field by the referee, A12 directs insulting language to the referee.
openA: A12 should be disqualified for insulting language. A12 cannot be replaced by 12-8-2f A9.
O1: A12 should receive a second caution and be disqualified for receiving a second caution. A12 can be replaced by A9.
O2: A12 should be disqualified for insulting language. A12 cannot be replaced by A9.
O3: A12 has already been cautioned and cannot be shown a second card in this situation.
O4: A12s actions are all part of the cautioning process and the referee should ignore his language.

Q: A7 is on a breakaway, one on one with goalkeeper B1, near the penalty spot. As A7 attempts to run around B1, B6 runs in from behind A7 and tugs A7s jersey, pulling him off balance. As A7 falls, his right foot kicks the ball weakly toward the goal and it crosses into the goal at the far post.
openA: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to 12-8-1f(14) leave the field of play and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B.
O1: The goal should not be counted, B6 should be shown the red card and disqualified and Team A should be awarded a penalty kick.
O2: The goal should not be counted, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to leave the field of play and Team A should be awarded a penalty kick.
O3: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the red card and disqualified and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B.
O4: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to leave the field of play and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: A7 receives a caution for a reckless tackle. Before leaving the field, or before a substitute has been beckoned in, A7 slams the ball down in protest.
openA: Display a second yellow and then a red card to A7 and not allow a substitute. 12-8-2c, 12-8-1c
O1: Display a red card to A7.
O2: Display a second yellow and then a red card to A7 and allow a substitute.
O3: Display a second yellow and then a red card to A7 and not allow a substitute.
O4: Have A7 leave the field for the first caution and take no further action.

Q: If the referee fails to signal the kick is indirect and the ball goes directly into the opponent's goal, the result shall be:
openA: Retake the indirect free kick. 13-3-4 (NEW)
O1: Retake the indirect free kick.
O2: Award a goal to the kicking team.
O3: A goal kick to the opposing team; goal is not allowed.
O4: Drop ball.

Q: B9 is tripped by A6. The referee stops play and awards a free kick to Team B. A6 remains at the spot of the foul, between the ball and the goal defended by Team A, arguing that B9 fell over his leg and that there was no trip.
openA: The referee should caution A6 and require him to leave the field of play. 12-8-1, 13-3-1
O1: The referee should caution A6 and require him to leave the spot of the foul.
O2: The referee should caution A6 for delaying the restart of play and also caution him for dissent. The referee should then disqualify A6 for receiving a second caution.
O3: The referee should ignore A6 and signal for the restart of play.
O4: The referee should move to a spot 10 yards closer to the goal defended by Team A and urge A6 to retreat to that position.

Q: A9 believes that he has been fouled by B4. The referee allows play to continue. A9 spits at the referee. If the referee stops play immediately, the referee should:
openA: Display a red card to A9 and restart play with an indirect kick. 13-2-2m
O1: Display a yellow card to A9 and restart play with a direct kick.
O2: Display a red card to A9 and restart play with an indirect kick.
O3: Display a red card to A9 and restart play with a direct kick.
O4: Display yellow card and restart with an indirect kick.

Q: If during a penalty kick the kick goes directly over the goal line outside the goal and there is a violation by the attacking team, the restart is:
openA: Goal kick.
O1: Goal kick.
O2: Retake.
O3: Corner Kick.
O4: Indirect free kick.

Q: Player A2, in taking a penalty kick, approaches the ball and then stops abruptly. The goalkeeper dives to the side. A2 then kicks the ball and scores.
openA: The referee shall rule no goal and order the kick to be retaken. 14-1-4, 14.1.4 SITUATION B
O1: The referee shall award a goal and restart with a kickoff.
O2: The referee shall rule no goal and order the kick to be retaken.
O3: The referee shall caution the player for unsporting conduct.
O4: The referee shall not award a goal and restart the game with a goal kick. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: The referee has awarded Team B a penalty kick. The goalkeeper, A1, stands with his back to the ball. The referee shall:
openA: Require the goalkeeper to face the kicker. 14-1-3
O1: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.
O2: Require the goalkeeper to face the kicker.
O3: Suspend the contest until the goalkeeper agrees to face the kicker.
O4: Declare a forfeit.

Q: B17 is being replaced on a legal substitution opportunity for her team. What should happen next?
openA: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, is beckoned 18-1-1gg onto the field by the referee.
O1: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, takes her position on the field.
O2: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, is beckoned onto the field by the referee.
O3: B17 is considered to still be a player until her replacement, B12, steps onto the field.
O4: B17 is considered to still be a player until she has left the field and the game has been restarted.

Q: The official signal for a goal scored is:
openA: Stopping the clock and pointing to the center of the field. Signal Chart
O1: Blowing the whistle.
O2: Raising both hands above the head.
O3: Stopping the clock.
O4: Stopping the clock and pointing to the center of the field.

Q: The goal to be used for penalty kicks as a part of an overtime procedure is determined by:
openA: Random selection.
O1: Random selection.
O2: Home Team.
O3: Head Referee.
O4: Visiting team.

Q: During inspection of the field, the referees note that the corner flags are not orange. What should be the referee's response?
openA: This is permitted. 1-3
O1: This is not permitted and the game may not begin until orange corner flags are provided.
O2: This is not permitted but the game may begin with corner flags that are not orange. The referee should notify the home team to correct the situation for future games.
O3: This is permitted.
O4: Since the corner flags are not the proper color, they should be removed before the game begins.

Q: Prior to the game, whether the field is unsafe for play and the game should be canceled is the responsibility of:
openA: The host athletic director. 1-7
O1: The visiting coach.
O2: The host athletic director.
O3: The host coach.
O4: The referee. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: The home team has painted the goals in its school colors: green and gold. What should the referee do?
openA: Inform the home coach that colored goals are illegal and must be corrected 1-4-1 by the next game, then notify the state association.
O1: Declare the game a forfeit and award the win to the visiting team.
O2: Inform the home coach that colored goals are illegal and must be corrected by the next game, then notify the state association.
O3: Ask the visiting coach if he or she wishes to play the game as scheduled.
O4: Nothing, just play the game.

Q: A game that must have a winner remains tied after overtime played under the NFHS Sample Tie-Breaking Procedure. The game will now proceed to a penalty kick tie-breaker. The team B coach informs the referee that he now wishes to add a player to his teams roster, a junior varsity team player who has been sitting in the stands during the game. The coach reports that this player is legally and properly equipped.
openA: This is not permitted.
O1: The referee must allow this addition to the roster.
O2: This is not permitted.
O3: This is only permitted with the permission of the opposing coach.
O4: Allow the JV player to kick after all others have kicked.

Q: A6 has banged heads with an opponent while trying to head a high ball. The referee has stopped play and has determined that A6 has the signs of a possible concussion. The referee requires A6 to leave the field and informs his coach that he may have suffered a concussion. There is no state association rule about concussions beyond that contained in the NFHS rules book.
openA: The referee may allow A6 to return to the game if the coach indicates 3-3-2b(3) appropriate medical personnel has cleared the player.
O1: The referee should not allow A6 to return to the game after being cleared by an appropriate health-care professional.
O2: The referee may allow A6 to return to the game if the coach indicates appropriate medical personnel has cleared the player.
O3: The referee should allow A6 to return to the game if his coach has him report in per 3-4-1.
O4: The referee should not allow A6 to return until the opponent is able to return.

Q: B10 is apparently injured. The referee has stopped play and summoned the Team B trainer onto the field of play.
openA: Both coaches may give their teams coaching instruction. 3.3.2 SITUATION H
O1: Neither coach may give coaching instruction to his or her players during the injury stoppage.
O2: The Team A coach may give instruction to the Team A players but the Team B coach must only attend to the injured player.
O3: The Team B coach may only give instructions to the substitute for B10.
O4: Both coaches may give their teams coaching instruction.

Q: B7 is injured and is required to leave the field. Team B has no available substitutes and, therefore, must play short. Several minutes later, B7 has recovered from his injury, and his coach has sent him to report in. What should happen next?
openA: B7 may enter the game at the next dead ball. 3.3.7 SITUATION A
O1: B7 may enter the game at the next legal substitution opportunity for his team.
O2: B7 may enter the game at the next dead ball.
O3: B7 may enter the game during the run of play.
O4: B7 may not enter the game until he has been cleared by a doctor in writing.

Q: During the cautioning and/or disqualification dead ball of bench personnel:
openA: Substitutes who have properly reported before the caution and/or 3-4-1d; 3-3-3e disqualification may be beckoned onto the field by the referee.
O1: Substitutes who have properly reported before the caution and/or disqualification may be beckoned onto the field by the referee.
O2: Only those substitutes who have reported in from the non-offending team may be beckoned onto the field.
O3: No substitutes are permitted at this time.
O4: Any player or bench personnel may substitute at this time. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: During the game, the referee notices that B30 has tape on her ear lobes. Closer observation indicates that there are earrings underneath the tape. The referee should:
openA: Wait until the next stoppage; and since this is the first caution for illegal 4-3, 18-1-1t equipment, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O1: Stop the game, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O2: Wait until the next stoppage; and since this is the first caution for illegal equipment, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O3: Wait until the next stoppage, feel B30s ear lobes to check for earrings under the tape and, if so, caution the Team B head coach and require B30 to leave the game.
O4: Since the referee did not notice the tape before the game, the referee should take no action.

Q: Play has been stopped for a foul by A4. The referee has stopped the clock and has given A4 a caution (yellow card.) As the referee is walking with the player towards the Team A bench to report the caution to the coaches, A4 directs insulting language to the referee. A9, a substitute of A4 who is waiting to enter the game for A4, has not been beckoned onto the field by the referee.
openA: The referee should show A4 a red card and not allow A9 to enter the field. 3-3-6, 12-8-2f
O1: The referee should ignore A4s statement.
O2: The referee should show A4 a red card and allow A9 to enter the field.
O3: The referee should show A4 a red card and not allow A9 to enter the field.
O4: The referee should show A4 a yellow card, followed by a red card and not allow A9 to enter the game.

Q: A player who is illegally equipped and whose coach is cautioned for the misconduct:
openA: Must leave the field of play and may not return until the next legal substitution 4-3, 18-1-1t opportunity.
O1: Must also be cautioned.
O2: Must leave the field of play and may not return until the next legal substitution opportunity.
O3: Must correct the illegal equipment but is not required to leave the field of play.
O4: Must leave the field of play and can return at the next dead ball.

Q: Before the game, the referee observes B4 wearing soft-padded headgear.
openA: B4 may participate. 4-2-9
O1: B4 may participate with soft-padded headgear only if a medical release signed by the appropriate medical professional is available.
O2: B4 may not participate with the soft-padded headgear.
O3: B4 may participate.
O4: B4 may participate with the soft-padded headgear only if both coaches agree.

Q: Before the game, the Team A head coach informs the referee that A15 will be wearing a hockey-style mask, due to an injury she received in a game the previous week.
openA: This is not permitted. 4-2-8, 4.2.1 SITUATION G
O1: This is not permitted.
O2: This is not permitted unless A15 can show the referee a doctors permission slip.
O3: This is permitted.
O4: This is permitted unless the mask has been painted in an objectionable manner.

Q: During the game, the referee notices several players with untucked jerseys. The referee should:
openA: Do nothing, as jerseys are not required to be tucked into the shorts. 4-1-1a
O1: Caution the offending players for improper uniform.
O2: Caution the head coach for having players with improper uniforms.
O3: Warn the players and have them tuck their jerseys.
O4: Do nothing, as jerseys are not required to be tucked into the shorts. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: Goalkeepers shall wear socks that:
openA: Must differ in color of opposing field players. 4-1-1h(3)
O1: Are the same color as their teammates.
O2: Must be different than the color of all other field players.
O3: Must differ in color of opposing field players.
O4: Must differ in color of opposing goalkeeper.

Q: Player A has a broken cheek bone and is wearing a protective face mask made of a hard material molded to the face. The referee shall allow A to play provided:
openA: A release signed by an appropriate health-care professional is on site. 4-2-8
O1: A signed release from A's parents is on site.
O2: A signed release from the school's athletic director is on site.
O3: A signed release from A's coach is presented to the referees.
O4: A release signed by an appropriate health-care professional is on site.

Q: The referee observes a foul, but does not penalize it because she perceives an advantage; however, the advantage does not develop.
openA: The referee will let play continue because advantage was given.
O1: The referee will let play continue because advantage was given.
O2: The referee will stop play caution the player who committed the original foul and re-start with an indirect free kick.
O3: The referee will stop play caution the player who committed the original foul and re-start with a direct free kick.
O4: The referee shall immediately stop play and penalize the original foul.

Q: Pregame conferences shall be conducted by the head referee.
openA: The pregame conference must be attended by the team's head coach and 5-2-2d captains.
O1: The opposing captains are the only ones required to attend the pregame conference.
O2: The head referee is not required to hold a pregame conference.
O3: The pregame conference must be attended by the team's head coach and captains.
O4: The pregame conference is the assistant referee's responsibility.

Q: B14 takes a shot on goal, with goalkeeper A1 out of position. A3, however, extends her arm into the path of the ball, deflecting it to B9. B9 shoots and the ball enters the goal.
openA: The referee should allow the goal and caution A3 for unsporting conduct. 5.3.1 SITUATION A, 12-8-1f
O1: The referee should award Team B a penalty kick and caution A3 for unsporting conduct.
O2: The referee should award Team B a penalty kick and disqualify A3 for serious foul play.
O3: The referee should allow the goal and caution A3 for unsporting conduct.
O4: The referee should allow the goal and disqualify A3 for serious foul play.

Q: Player A1 is on an attack, kicks the ball and it deflects off the referee to Player B1. What is the appropriate procedure?
openA: The officials should stop play and conduct a drop ball with one player from 9-1-1(b)3, 9-2-3 Team A at the position where it was last touched by the official.
O1: The official should let play continue, so as not to disrupt the advantage by Team A.
O2: The officials should stop play and award an indirect free kick to Team A.
O3: The officials should stop play and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O4: The officials should stop play and conduct a drop ball with one player from Team A at the position where it was last touched by the official. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: The ball goes directly into the opponent's goal from a corner kick. The referee should:
openA: Allow the goal. 10-1-2e
O1: Disallow the goal.
O2: Allow the goal only if the ball was played twice before entering the goal.
O3: Allow the goal.
O4: None of the above.

Q: A10 is in an offside position. After receiving a pass from B7, B9 accidentally passes the ball to A10. A10 should be:
openA: Allowed to continue with play. 11-1-4 SITUATION A
O1: Penalized for being offside and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Issued a caution for being offside and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O3: Allowed to continue with play.
O4: Awarded a drop ball.

Q: A2, in an offside position, receives a goal kick taken by B1. The referee shall:
openA: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule. 11-1-2
O1: Penalize Team A for A2 being offside.
O2: Only call offside if a goal is scored.
O3: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.
O4: None of the above.

Q: A2, standing with the ball on his own half of the field and seeing A4 streaking for the goal, kicks the ball over the heads of the Team B defenders between himself and A4. B6 reaches over his head and knocks down the ball. A4 was in an offside position when A2 passed him the ball.
openA: A4 is guilty of offside. The referee should award Team B an indirect free kick. 11-1-2 SITUATION D The referee may warn B6 about his actions but does not have to caution him.
O1: B6 is guilty of handling. The referee should award Team A a direct free kick.
O2: B6 is guilty of handling. The referee should award Team A a direct free kick and caution B6 for unsporting behavior.
O3: A4 is guilty of offside. The referee should award Team B an indirect free kick. The referee should caution B6 for unsporting behavior.
O4: A4 is guilty of offside. The referee should award Team B an indirect free kick. The referee may warn B6 about his actions but does not have to caution him.

Q: B19 is standing in an offside position. B12 kicks the ball forward but the ball deflects off A11 to B19. B19 should be:
openA: Penalized for being offside. 11-1-4b, DIAGRAM 12
O1: Allowed to continue with play as long as B19 passes the ball to B12.
O2: Allowed to continue with play.
O3: Penalized for being offside.
O4: Issued a caution for being offside.

Q: A player shall be disqualified, without caution, by the official when he or she has completed the following action:
openA: Flagrantly fouls the goalkeeper who is in possession of the ball. 12-4-2a
O1: Hand ball.
O2: Kicks the ball out of bounds.
O3: Flagrantly fouls the goalkeeper who is in possession of the ball.
O4: Fakes an injury. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: A14 is running toward the goal. Her teammate, A12, kicks the ball toward A14. A14 did not see the ball coming and the ball strikes her in the back of the hand as her hand is at her side. The proper call would be to:
openA: Allow play to continue. 12-2
O1: Award an indirect free kick to Team B for incidental contact.
O2: Award a direct free kick to Team B.
O3: Allow play to continue as the handling was incidental but issue a caution to the player at the next stoppage of play.
O4: Allow play to continue.

Q: A7 fell near the ball due to his own clumsiness. There is no opponent near him. While still on the ground, A7 kicks the ball to A12. The referee should:
openA: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule. 12.6 SITUATION D
O1: Award Team B an indirect free kick.
O2: Allow play to continue as this is permitted by rule.
O3: Caution A7 and award a direct free kick.
O4: Caution A7 at the next stoppage.

Q: A7 is on a breakaway, one-on-one with goalkeeper B1, at about the penalty spot. As A7 attempts to run around B1, B6 runs in from behind A7 and tugs A7s jersey, pulling him off balance. As A7 falls, his right foot kicks the ball weakly towards the touchline. A9 runs in from behind A7 and kicks the ball into the goal.
openA: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to 12-8-1f(14) leave the field of play and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B.
O1: The goal should not be counted, B6 should be shown the red card and disqualified and Team A should be awarded a penalty kick.
O2: The goal should not be counted, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to leave the field of play and Team A should be awarded a penalty kick.
O3: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the red card and disqualified and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B.
O4: The goal should count, B6 should be shown the yellow card and required to leave the field of play and the game should be restarted with a kickoff by Team B.

Q: After a stoppage for an injury, A9 takes a throw-in. Goalkeeper A1 catches the ball while standing in his own penalty area.
openA: A1 has touched the ball directly from a teammates throw-in. The referee 12.7.4 SITUATION should award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O1: A1 is guilty of deliberately handling the ball. The referee should award a penalty kick to Team B.
O2: A1 has touched the ball directly from a teammates throw-in. The referee should award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O3: A9 is guilty of a pass back and the referee should award Team B an indirect free kick.
O4: A1 is not guilty of an offense. Play should continue.

Q: Player A2 takes a penalty kick during the game. The ball rebounds off the goalpost directly to A2 who shoots and scores.
openA: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with an indirect kick. 14-1-5
O1: The referee shall allow the goal.
O2: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with an indirect kick.
O3: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with a goal kick.
O4: The referee shall order the kick retaken.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, A7 uses several stutter-steps but does not interrupt the approach to the ball. The ball enters the goal. The referee should:
openA: Allow the goal and restart with a kickoff by the defending team. 14-1-4
O1: Allow the goal and restart with a kickoff by the defending team.
O2: Disallow the goal and retake the kick.
O3: Disallow the goal and restart with an indirect kick for Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal, caution A7 for unsporting play and restart with an indirect kick for Team B. Copyright  1990-2021 National Federation of State High School Associations. All rights reserved.

Q: During a penalty kick, Player A2 kicks the ball and the ball becomes deflated when it hits the crossbar. What is the appropriate restart?
openA: Retake the penalty kick.
O1: Retake the penalty kick.
O2: Goal kick awarded to Team B.
O3: Corner kick awarded to Team A.
O4: Indirect free kick for Team B.

Q: During the game, the referee notices several players with untucked jerseys. The referee should:
openA: Do nothing, as jerseys are not required to be tucked into the shorts.
O1: Caution the offending players for improper uniform.
O2: Caution the head coach for having players with improper uniforms.
O3: Warn the players and have them tuck their jerseys.
O4: Do nothing, as jerseys are not required to be tucked into the shorts.

Q: A pass by A2 to A3 strikes the referee who is standing in the penalty area. The ball remains on the field of play and is controlled by B2. What is the appropriate restart?
openA: Drop ball to the team that last touched the ball.
O1: Indirect free kick.
O2: Throw-in.
O3: Drop ball to the team that last touched the ball prior to hitting the referee.
O4: Drop ball to the defending goalkeeper.

Q: Player A1 is on an attack, kicks the ball and it deflects off the referee to Player B1. What is the appropriate procedure?
openA: The officials should stop play and conduct a drop ball with one player from Team A 9-1-1(b)3, 9-2-3 at the position where it was last touched by the official.
O1: The official should let play continue, so as not to disrupt the advantage by Team A.
O2: The officials should stop play and award an indirect free kick to Team A.
O3: The officials should stop play and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O4: The officials should stop play and conduct a drop ball with one player from Team A at the position where it was last touched by the official.

Q: If Team A, while defending, is awarded an indirect free kick inside the penalty area, the opposing plays shall stand:
openA: Outside the penalty area, at least
O1: Outside the penalty area, at least 10 yards from the ball.
O2: At least 10 yards from the ball, regardless of ball placement.
O3: Outside the penalty area, at least 10 yards from the ball, until the ball is in play.
O4: At least 4 yards from the ball.

Q: If the referee fails to signal the kick is indirect and the ball goes directly into the opponent's goal, the result shall be:
openA: Retake the indirect free kick.
O1: Retake the indirect free kick.
O2: Award a goal to the kicking team.
O3: A goal kick to the opposing team; goal is not allowed.
O4: Drop ball.

Q: A10 is in an offside position. After receiving a pass from B7, B9 accidentally passes the ball to A10. The official shall:
openA: Allow play to continue.
O1: Penalize for being offside and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Issue a caution for being offside and award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Award a drop ball.

Q: A3 receives the ball directly from a corner kick taken by A5, while A3 is standing in an offside position. The official shall:
openA: Allow play to continue.
O1: Caution A3 and award an indirect free kick to the opposing team.
O2: Caution A3 and retake the corner kick.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Issue a verbal waring for being in an offside position

Q: During active play, Substitute/Bench Player B12 mistakenly thinks the ball has gone out of bounds and kicks the ball toward a teammate who is in play.
openA: Award Team A a direct kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball and caution
O1: Award Team A a direct kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball and caution B12.
O2: Award Team A an indirect kick from the point where B12 kicked the ball.
O3: Resume play with a drop ball at the point where B12 kicked the ball.
O4: Allow play to continue with no stoppage.

Q: If a goal kick is touched twice by the kicker before another player has touched the ball, what is the proper penalty?
openA: Indirect kick from the spot of the infraction.
O1: The goal kick is taken again.
O2: Yellow card to the kicker and the kick is taken again.
O3: Indirect kick from the spot of the infraction.
O4: Direct kick taken from the closest position outside of the penalty area.

Q: A goal may be scored directly from a:
openA: Goal Kick.
O1: Throw-in.
O2: Dropped Ball.
O3: Goal Kick.
O4: Goal kick into a team's own goal.

Q: In which case should a goal be allowed?
openA: The entire ball is beyond the goal line.
O1: A portion of the ball is on the goal line.
O2: A portion of the ball is beyond the goal line.
O3: The entire ball is beyond the goal line.
O4: None of the above.

Q: A goal may NOT be scored directly from a:
openA: Goalkeeper's throw.
O1: Kickoff.
O2: Direct kick.
O3: Punt.
O4: Goalkeeper's throw.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, the kick rebounds off the goalkeeper back to an attacking player who entered the penalty area early. What happens?
openA: Indirect free kick.
O1: Retake the penalty kick.
O2: Play continues.
O3: Indirect free kick.
O4: Goal kick.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, the kick rebounds off the goalkeeper's back to a defending player who entered the penalty area early. What happens?
openA: Retake the penalty kick.
O1: Retake the penalty kick.
O2: Play continues.
O3: Indirect free kick.
O4: Goal kick.

Q: A1, an offensive player, steps off the field to avoid being called for offside. What is the ruling?
openA: Legal. A1 can leave the field if for the sole purpose of not being offside.
O1: Illegal. Offside should be called on A1.
O2: Illegal. A1 should be cautioned for the action.
O3: Legal. A1 can leave the field if for the sole purpose of not being offside.
O4: Illegal. Team A's head coach should be cautioned.

Q: A10, in an offside position, receives a header from B10. What is the ruling?
openA: Legal. A10 should be allowed to play the ball as it was last played by an opponent.
O1: Illegal. A10 should be called for offside.
O2: Legal. A10 should be allowed to play the ball as it was last played by an opponent.
O3: Legal, but A10 cannot score from the succeeding play on the ball.
O4: Illegal. A10 did not receive the ball from a deliberate play.

Q: A4 is in an offside position on the opponent's half of the field. A5 passes the ball to A4 who returns to A4's own half of the field and receives the ball.
openA: Illegal. A4 is still defined as offside.
O1: Legal. A4 is no longer offside upon return to A4's own half of the field.
O2: Legal. A4 negates the offside by returning to A4's half of the field.
O3: Illegal. A4 is still defined as offside.
O4: Illegal. A4 should be cautioned for unsporting play.

Q: Spectators enter the field and disrupt play. What does the referee have the authority to do?
openA: Terminate or suspend the game.
O1: Stop play and caution the coach of the team that the spectators represent.
O2: Stop play and disqualify the coach of the team that the spectators represent.
O3: Terminate or suspend the game.
O4: None of the above.

Q: The home team shall provide ball holders for the game.
openA: At least two ball holders must be provided by the home team.
O1: This is a requirement or the game cannot be played.
O2: At least two ball holders must be provided by the home team.
O3: At least two ball holders must be provided by the visiting team.
O4: There must be at least four ball holders assigned to the game.

Q: A player is cautioned and the referee orders the clock to be stopped:
openA: Time is restarted when the ball is properly put into play.
O1: The official timer restarts the clock when the cautioned player leaves the field.
O2: Time is restarted when the ball is properly put into play.
O3: Time is restarted when the referee blows the whistle.
O4: As soon as the substitute enters the field, time is restarted.

Q: What happens when the referee inadvertently sounds the whistle?
openA: The referee stops play and awards a dropped ball to a player of the team last in 9-2-1c possession, or to the defending team's goalkeeper if the ball was in the penalty area, when play was stopped.
O1: Realizing the error, the referee verbally directs "play on" to the players to continue play.
O2: The referee stops play and awards a dropped ball to a player of the team last in possession, or to the defending team's goalkeeper if the ball was in the penalty area, when play was stopped.
O3: The referee stops play and awards an indirect kick to the team in possession.
O4: The referee should do nothing and allow play to continue.

Q: B19 is standing in an offside position. B12 kicks the ball forward but the ball deflects off A11 to B19. B19 should be:
openA: Penalized
O1: Allowed to continue with play as long as B19 passes the ball to B12.
O2: Allowed to continue with play.
O3: Penalized for being offside.
O4: Issued a caution for being offside.

Q: Player A of the attacking team is clearly in an offside position when Player A's teammate delivers the ball to Player A with a throw-in. Player A collects the ball and kicks it into the goal. The referee should:
openA: Award a goal to Team A.
O1: Award an indirect free kick to Team B.
O2: Award a goal to Team A.
O3: Award a goal kick to Team B.
O4: Award a re-take to Team A.

Q: Player A, who is in an offside position, receives the ball from a goal kick by A2.
openA: There is no offside violation and play is allowed to continue.
O1: The assistant referee raises the flag to indicate offside.
O2: The assistant referee indicates offside violation and the referee stops play and awards an indirect free kick.
O3: There is no offside violation and play is allowed to continue.
O4: Stop play and retake the goal kick.

Q: The referee has awarded Team B a penalty kick. As B4 runs toward the ball to take the kick, A5 enters the penalty area before B4 kicks the ball. The referee should:
openA: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal.
O1: Blow the whistle as soon as A enters the penalty area.
O2: Allow the play to continue and award a goal if the kick by B4 enters the goal.
O3: Allow the play to continue and award a goal kick if the kick by B4 goes untouched over the goal.
O4: Allow the play to continue and award a corner kick if the kick by B4 is played by the goalkeeper who pushes the ball over the goal line outside of the goal.

Q: Player A2 takes a penalty kick during the game. The ball rebounds off the goalpost directly to A2 who shoots and scores.
openA: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with an indirect kick.
O1: The referee shall allow the goal.
O2: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with an indirect kick.
O3: The referee shall not allow the goal and restart with a goal kick.
O4: The referee shall order the kick retaken.

Q: If on a penalty kick there is a deflection out of bounds by the goalkeeper and no violation by either team, the restart is a:
openA: Corner
O1: Retake.
O2: Indirect free kick.
O3: Corner kick.
O4: Goal kick.

Q: Player As throw-in lands completely outside the touchline, without having broken the plane of the touchline, and bounds into the field of play.
openA: The referee orders a re-throw .
O1: The referee orders a re-throw by Team A since the ball never was put into play.
O2: The referee awards a throw-in to Team B.
O3: The referee allows play to continue.
O4: The referee issues a team caution for delay of game.

Q: A2 receives a goal kick in the attacking half of the field from A1. There are not at least two opponents nearer their own goal line when A2 receives the ball directly from A1.
openA: A2 is not offside since a player cannot be offside when receiving the ball directly
O1: A2 should be ruled offside because there are not at least two opponents nearer their own goal than A2 when the ball is received.
O2: The official rules "play on."
O3: A2 is not offside since a player cannot be offside when receiving the ball directly from a goal kick.
O4: The official blows the whistle and gives Team B an indirect kick for the violation.

Q: The home teams logo obscures the halfway line. What is the best referee response?
openA: The field is illegal, but the official should start the game and notify the state
O1: The field is not properly marked. Do not start the game.
O2: Request the school administrator apply temporary paint to form a halfway line, then start the game.
O3: The field is illegal, but the official should start the game and notify the state association following the game.
O4: The field is legal. Start the game.

Q: During inspection of the field, the referee determines the penalty area is 45 yards wide. What is the best referee response?
openA: Start the game and use the lines as marked. Contact the state association after the
O1: The field is illegally marked. Do not start the game.
O2: Start the game, but make a mental note of where the boundary should be and make calls using the mental/invisible lines.
O3: Start the game and use the lines as marked. Contact the state association after the game.
O4: Ask coaches if they wish to play the game with the mis-marked field.

Q: The home team and the visiting team are both wearing white shorts.
openA: This is permitted.
O1: The referee should not begin the game until the home team is wearing dark shorts.
O2: This is permitted.
O3: The referee should not begin the game until the home team is wearing a different color shorts than the visiting team.
O4: The home team should change to dark shorts. If unable to correct, the game shall be played and the referee must notify the state association following the game.

Q: If the ball becomes deflated during play, it is declared dead and resumes by:
openA: Drop ball at the spot where it was last played to the team that last possesed the ball.
O1: Direct free kick.
O2: Indirect free kick.
O3: Indirect free kick at the spot where it was last played to the team that last possesed the ball.
O4: Drop ball at the spot where it was last played to the team that last possesed the ball.

Q: Which of the following needs to be included on the team roster:
openA: All of the above.
O1: Players.
O2: Bench personnel
O3: Coaches.
O4: All of the above.

Q: The visiting team arrives at the game site and the goalies jersey does not have a number.
openA: The visiting team should change to a legal goalie jersey. If unable to correct the 4-1-1 game shall be played and the referee must notify the state association following the game.
O1: The visiting team should change to a legal goalie jersey. If unable to correct the game shall be played and the referee must notify the state association following the game.
O2: The game should not start until corrected.
O3: The officials should allow the game to start, but caution the head coach before kickoff.
O4: The officials should allow the game to begin but caution the head coach at the first stoppage.

Q: A player enters the game wearing beads in the hair that are securely wrapped in a bun and secured to the head. The official shall:
openA: Take no action and allow the player to enter. The hair adornment is legal.
O1: Require the player to leave the game.
O2: Issue a caution to the player and at the next stoppage of play have the player replaced or rectify the issue.
O3: Take no action and allow the player to enter. The hair adornment is legal.
O4: Card the head coach and replace the player.

Q: The hosting school schedules a junior varsity and varsity match on the same day. After the JV match has concluded, the visiting JV team stays to watch its varsity team. During the match, the JV players from the spectator stands are shouting comments containing abusive language toward the referees that are causing game management issues. The referee should:
openA: Suspend the match and request the home school administration to take appropriate
O1: Allow play to continue and ignore the comments from the spectators.
O2: Suspend the match and request the home school administration to take appropriate action with the JV team members.
O3: Stop play and yell up to the stands a warning that the game will be suspended and or terminated if their behavior continues.
O4: Stop play and direct the JV players to leave the playing area and board their schools bus for the remainder of the varsity match.

Q: Player A1 passes the ball to A3 using the shoulder area above the armpit. The referee should:
openA: Allow play to continue.
O1: Blow the whistle and award a direct free kick to a player from Team B for handling.
O2: Blow the whistle and award an indirect free kick to a player from Team B for an accidental handling.
O3: Allow play to continue.
O4: Blow the whistle and award an indirect free kick to a player from Team A for an unintentional handling.

Q: The goalkeeper for Team A is wearing light blue socks. The goalkeeper's teammates are wearing black socks.
openA: Legal as long as Team B is not wearing light blue socks.
O1: Legal as long as Team B is not wearing light blue socks.
O2: The official must send the goalkeeper off until a change is made to black socks to match teammates.
O3: Legal even if the opposing team is also wearing light blue socks.
O4: Legal as long as the socks match the goalkeeper's jersey.

Q: With 1 minute and 30 seconds left in the first half of play, Team A has a two-goal lead. When the ball goes out of play for a goal kick, Team A makes a substitution. The official timer should:
openA: Notify the official of the substitution.
O1: Notify the official of the substitution.
O2: Notify the official of the substitution and stop the clock since the team in the lead is subbing.
O3: Disallow the substitution and do not notify the official.
O4: Notify the official of the substitution and stop the clock until the losing team also makes a substitution.

Q: B2 is pulled down by the jersey by A5. The referee stops play and awards a free kick to Team B. A5 then picks up the ball and begins walking away with the ball yelling the player fell down on his own.
openA: The referee should caution A5 and require A5 to leave the field of play.
O1: The referee should grab the ball out of the player's hand and place in spot of the foul and signal for the restart of play
O2: The referee should ignore A5 and wait until he puts the ball down
O3: The referee should give Team B 2 more yards for its free kick.
O4: The referee should caution A5 and require A5 to leave the field of play.

Q: After a goal by Team B, a player on Team A stands in the opponents half of the field and kicks the ball backward after the official blows the whistle to restart the game. Before the ball is touched by another player, the same player kicks the ball again to redirect it.
openA: This is illegal and Team B should be awarded an indirect free kick.
O1: This is legal and play should continue.
O2: This is illegal and the kick should be retaken.
O3: This is illegal and Team B should be awarded a direct free kick.
O4: This is illegal and Team B should be awarded an indirect free kick.

Q: The goalkeeper, before taking a goal kick, moves from the right side of the goal area to the left side of the goal area before spotting the ball.
openA: This is allowed, but if this is deemed a time-wasting ploy, the referee shall stop the
O1: Immediately stop play and give corner kick to opponent.
O2: The referee shall stop the clock and restart once the ball is put into play.
O3: If this is considered time-wasting, the referee shall award an indirect kick.
O4: This is allowed, but if this is deemed a time-wasting ploy, the referee shall stop the clock and caution the goalkeeper.

Q: During the taking of a penalty kick, kicker B2 plays the ball backward to teammate B5 who shoots and scores a goal. What happens next?
openA: Indirect free kick for defending team.
O1: Rekick.
O2: Allow goal.
O3: Indirect free kick for defending team.
O4: Goal kick.

Q: The referee observes Player A1 wearing socks with the foot cut off.
openA: This is legal as long as the visible material under the sock (and above the ankle) is
O1: This is illegal. Cut socks cannot be worn.
O2: This is illegal. The color of the foot of the sock must match the body of the sock.
O3: This is legal as long as the visible material under the sock (and above the ankle) is similar in color to the predominant color of the sock.
O4: This is legal. The color of the visible material under the sock does not matter.

Q: On a corner kick the defending team should be positioned 10 yards away from:
openA: Corner arc.
O1: Ball.
O2: Corner flag.
O3: Corner arc.
O4: Touchline.

Q: Team A is in the lead during the last five minutes of the game. Team B has a player who has reported to the official area and is ready to substitute. Team A then sends a player to report to the official area and is ready to substitute. The ball goes out of play and Team B is awarded a throw-in. The official shall:
openA: Allow the substitutions and the clock is not stopped.
O1: Not stop the clock if both teams are substituting.
O2: Allow the substitutions and the clock is not stopped.
O3: Stop the clock for the substitutions.
O4: Caution the Team A coach for unsporting behavior.

Q: A player from Team B kicks the ball toward a teammate but the ball strikes the hand of a player from Team A whose back is to the kicker and whose hand is at the side. The referee should:
openA: Allow play to continue as no foul occurred.
O1: Award an indirect free kick to a player from Team B.
O2: Award a direct free kick to a player from Team B.
O3: Award a drop ball to the kicker fromTeam B.
O4: Allow play to continue as no foul occurred.

Q: Each team shall submit a team roster. Which is not permissible to do once the game starts?
openA: All of the above are permissible.
O1: Add players to the roster.
O2: Change uniform numbers on the roster.
O3: Add bench personnel to the roster.
O4: All of the above are permissible. Video Question 51 Link - - https://nfhs.box.com/s/3y9bcpp8eal7gj5zkpzip3rr1z59vxv6

Q: The jurisdiction of the officials shall begin:
openA: On arrival at the field of play and its immediate surroundings. 5-1-2
O1: No later than 15 minutes prior to the start of the game.
O2: On arrival at the field of play and its immediate surroundings.
O3: As soon as the game starts.
O4: As soon as the referee enters the field of play.

Q: Goalkeeper A1 is waiting for a high ball to come down in close vicinity. As it reaches A1 and seeing B9 approaching, A1 jumps up for the ball with both hands extended. B9 comes running into the area and jumps up for the ball, attempting to head it into the goal. A1 and B9 collide, causing both to fall to the ground.
openA: Neither A1 nor B9 is guilty of any offense. The referee should allow play to 12-4-4 SITUATION A(a) continue, unless one or both players are injured.
O1: A1 is guilty of obstruction. The referee should award Team B an indirect free kick.
O2: B9 is guilty of an illegal charge. The referee should award Team A an indirect free kick.
O3: B9 is guilty of dangerous play. The referee should award Team A an indirect free kick.
O4: Neither A1 nor B9 is guilty of any offense. The referee should allow play to continue, unless one or both players are injured.

Q: The referee awards a throw-in to Team A. A14 takes the throw, but the ball hits the ground outside the touchline before entering the field. The referee should:
openA: Allow Team A to retake the throw.
O1: Allow play to continue, ball is in play.
O2: Allow Team A to retake the throw.
O3: Allow the throw-in to Team B from the same location.
O4: Administer a drop ball at the spot where the ball touched the ground.

Q: A dark jersey is defined as:
openA: Any color that contrasts with white. 4-1-1b
O1: Black.
O2: Any color other than white.
O3: Any color that contrasts with white.
O4: Any color that incorporates black.

Q: After Team A scores a goal, the assistant referee hears the Team A head coach calling one of the team's players, A15, off the field. The assistant referee counts the Team A players now on the field and realizes that Team A had 12 players on the field when the goal was scored. The assistant referee notifies the referee of this. The referee should:
openA: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a goal kick taken by Team B. 3-1-1 SITUATION B(a), 12-8-1a
O1: Allow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a kickoff by Team B.
O2: Allow the goal and restart with a kickoff by Team B, with no caution to A15.
O3: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a kickoff by Team B.
O4: Disallow the goal, caution A15 and restart with a goal kick taken by Team B.
